# Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets

Yuri Fukaya   [yuri.fukaya@ec.okayama-u.ac.jp](mailto:%20yuri.fukaya@ec.okayama-u.ac.jp)  Faculty of Environmental Life, Natural Science and Technology, Okayama University, 700-8530 Okayama, Japan     Bo Lu   [billmarx@tju.edu.cn](mailto:%20billmarx@tju.edu.cn)  Center for Joint Quantum Studies, Tianjin Key Laboratory of Low Dimensional Materials Physics and Preparing Technology, Department of Physics, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300354, China     Keiji Yada   [yada.keiji.b8@f.mail.nagoya-u.ac.jp](mailto:%20yada.keiji.b8@f.mail.nagoya-u.ac.jp)  Department of Applied Physics, Nagoya University, 464-8603 Nagoya, Japan     Yukio Tanaka   [ytanaka@nuap.nagoya-u.ac.jp](mailto:%20ytanaka@nuap.nagoya-u.ac.jp)  Department of Applied Physics, Nagoya University, 464-8603 Nagoya, Japan  Research Center for Crystalline Materials Engineering, Nagoya University, 464-8603 Nagoya, Japan     Jorge Cayao   [jorge.cayao@physics.uu.se](mailto:%20jorge.cayao@physics.uu.se)  Department of Physics and Astronomy, Uppsala University, Box 516, S-751 20 Uppsala, Sweden

(August 4, 2025)

###### Abstract

In this work we review the recent advances on superconducting phenomena in junctions formed by superconductors and unconventional magnets. Conventional magnets, such as ferromagnets and antiferromagnets, are characterized by broken time-reversal symmetry but only ferromagnets produce a finite net magnetization due to parallel spin alignment and spin-split bands in momentum. Very recently, a new type of magnets has been reported and here we refer to them as *unconventional magnets* because they exhibit special properties of both ferromagnets and antiferromagnets: they exhibit zero net magnetization (like antiferromagnets) and a nonrelativistic spin splitting of energy bands (like ferromagnets), both leading to anisotropic spin-polarized Fermi surfaces. An interesting property of unconventional magnets is that their magnetic order can be even or odd with respect to momentum, where *-wave altermagnets* and *-wave magnets* are the most representative examples. In this regard, -wave altermagnets and -wave magnets are seen as counterparts in magnetism of the unconventional - and -wave superconducting states, respectively. While the impact of conventional magnetism on superconductivity has been largely studied, the combination of unconventional magnets and superconductivity has only lately attracted considerably attention. This work provides a comprehensive review of the recent progress on the interplay between superconductivity and unconventional magnets. In particular, we focus on the fundamental emerging superconducting phenomena and also discuss the potential implications towards quantum applications.

## I Introduction

Superconductivity and magnetism were initially saw to be incompatible due to the destruction of spin-singlet Cooper pairs by the exchange field but their combination was later shown to be the key for novel superconducting phenomena and quantum applications [[1](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib1), [2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib2), [3](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib3), [4](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib4), [5](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib5), [6](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib6), [7](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib7), [8](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib8)]. One salient example is the realization of spin-triplet Cooper pairs [[1](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib1)], which not only characterize an emergent spin-triplet superconducting phase but also represent the key for superconducting spintronics [[3](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib3), [4](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib4), [5](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib5), [6](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib6), [7](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib7), [8](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib8)], topological superconductivity and Majorana zero modes [[9](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib9), [10](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib10), [11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib11), [12](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib12), [13](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib13), [14](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib14), [15](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib15), [16](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib16), [17](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib17)], and superconducting qubits [[18](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib18), [19](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib19), [20](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib20), [21](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib21), [22](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib22), [23](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib23), [24](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib24)]. The role of magnetism for converting spin-singlet Cooper pairs into spin-triplet ones is crucial, an aspect that has been mostly studied in superconducting systems formed by ferromagnets (FMs) and antiferromagnets (AFMs), see e. g., Refs. [[25](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib25), [4](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib4), [5](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib5), [26](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib26), [27](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib27), [28](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib28), [29](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib29), [30](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib30), [8](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib8)]. FMs and AFMs are examples of collinear magnetism arising from the spontaneous arrangements of magnetic moments oriented parallel and antiparallel to each other, respectively [[31](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib31), [32](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib32), [33](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib33), [34](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib34)]; whenever necessary, FMs and AFMs will be referred to as conventional magnets. In both types of these conventional magnets, time reversal symmetry is broken, but only FMs exhibit a finite net magnetization and spin-split electronic bands [[35](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib35), [36](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib36), [37](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib37), [38](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib38)]. While both FMs and AFMs have been shown to promote novel superconducting phases, in terms of applications both posses considerable challenges. For instance, the finite net magnetization of FMs, useful in some situations [[39](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib39)], is detrimental for scalability and stability of superconductor-FM devices [[40](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib40), [41](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib41), [42](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib42)]; moreover, AFMs are excellent in terms of scalability due to zero net magnetization [[43](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib43), [38](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib38), [39](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib39)], they do not host the useful spin-dependent effects of FMs, which difficulties reading data stored in AFMs [[40](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib40), [41](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib41), [42](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib42)]. It would be therefore desirable to realize magnetic phases containing the positive properties of both AFMs and FMs, such that, when combining with superconductivity, the emergent superconducting phase can be useful for realistic applications.

Recently, a new family of magnetic materials with properties akin to both FMs and AFMs has been predicted [[44](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib44), [45](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib45), [46](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib46), [47](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib47), [48](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib48), [49](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib49), [50](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib50), [51](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib51), [52](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib52)]. These new magnets have been shown to have zero net magnetization (like AFMs) and a spin-splitting of electronic bands (like FMs) that depends on momentum but of nonrelativistic origin [[53](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib53), [54](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib54), [55](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib55), [56](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib56), [57](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib57)] and hence distinct from common spin-orbit coupling [[58](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib58), [59](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib59)]. For these reasons, the new magnets are known as *unconventional magnets* [[60](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib60), [51](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib51), [61](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib61), [62](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib62), [52](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib52)]. A particular consequence of the momentum dependent spin-split energy bands in unconventional magnets is that they exhibit anisotropic spin-polarized Fermi surfaces in momentum space as well as a momentum dependent magnetic order that can have even- [[53](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib53), [54](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib54)] and odd-parity [[55](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib55), [56](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib56), [57](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib57)], akin to what happens in unconventional superconductors [[63](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib63), [64](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib64)]. The even-parity magnetic order can have -, -, -, or -wave symmetries, corresponding to the degree , , , or of the exchange magnetic field polynomials with momenta space as variables. Similarly, the odd-parity magnetic order can have - or -wave symmetries, corresponding to the degree or of the exchange magnetic field in momentum. The simplest unconventional magnets, where the even- and odd-parity exchange fields are quadratic and linear in momenta, have so far attracted an enormous attention and were coined -wave altermagnets (AMs) [[53](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib53), [54](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib54)] and -wave magnets [[55](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib55), [56](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib56), [57](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib57)], respectively. In what follows we will refer to all the even-parity unconventional magnets as to AMs, of course indicating always the type of parity symmetry. Even though the intriguing spin-momentum locking and spin splitting in both types of unconventional magnets have a nonrelativistic origin, they originate from distinct symmetries that is different for even- and odd-parity unconventional magnets. For instance, AMs are collinear-compensated magnets in real space where time-reversal symmetry is broken but inversion symmetry is preserved [[53](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib53), [54](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib54)]; atoms in AMs exhibit an alternating spin direction and spatial orientation on the neighbouring sites. Moreover, AMs break time-reversal symmetry but preserve inversion symmetry, while opposite spins are connected by crystal rotation or mirror symmetries [[53](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib53), [54](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib54)]. A recent study suggested that the concept of AMs can be extended to non-collinear spins as well [[65](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib65)], which certainly expands the materials search of altermagnetism. On the other hand, -wave magnets are noncollinear and noncoplanar magnets, protected by the combination of time-reversal and a translation of a half the unit cell, where time-reversal symmetry is preserved but inversion symmetry is broken [[55](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib55), [56](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib56), [57](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib57)].

All the intriguing properties of unconventional magnets have inspired a large number of theoretical and experimental studies in the normal state, although mostly in AMs, see Refs.  [[44](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib44), [45](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib45), [46](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib46), [48](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib48), [49](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib49), [50](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib50), [51](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib51), [52](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib52)]. At the moment, there already are around 60 materials predicted to host altermagnetism [[53](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib53), [54](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib54), [66](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib66)]; among the predicted materials, CrSb and MnTe are believed to be -wave AMs, while RuO2, Mn5Si3, MnF2 and MnO2 are expected to be -wave AMs. Several of these materials have already been measured to be altermagnetic, such as V2Se2O and V2Te2O [[50](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib50), [67](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib67), [68](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib68), [69](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib69)], RuO2 [[45](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib45), [70](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib70), [71](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib71)], Mn5Si3 [[72](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib72), [73](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib73)], La2CuO4 [[74](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib74)], MnTe [[75](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib75), [76](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib76), [77](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib77)], MnTe2 [[78](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib78)], Weyl semimetal CrSb [[79](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib79), [80](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib80)]. It is thus evident that the peculiar nonrelativistic spin splitting and spin-momentum locking in unconventional magnets make them promising for spin-dependent effects, with strong implications towards scalable spintronic devices in the normal state [[61](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib61)].

The properties of unconventional magnets have also triggered a great deal of attention in the superconducting state, placing unconventional magnetism as the key mechanism to engineer novel superconducting phenomena while maintaining zero net magnetization. In this regard, emergent superconducting states have been explored as intrinsic effects and also as induced phenomena at interfaces of hybrid junctions when coupling unconventional magnets and superconductors. The first study on the intrinsic coexistence of altermagnetism and superconductivity as well as the possibility of superconductivity due to AM spin fluctuations was theoretically carried out in 2022 [[141](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib141)], almost immediately after the prediction of AMs in the normal state. Later, it was shown that such intrinsic coexistence of altermagnetism and superconductivity can promote finite momentum superconductivity without any net magnetization [[142](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib142), [143](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib143), [144](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib144), [145](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib145), [146](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib146), [147](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib147)], and, to date, there exist signs of this coexistence effect in strained RuO2 [[148](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib148), [149](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib149), [150](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib150)] and in monolayer FeSe [[151](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib151)]; see also Ref. [[152](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib152)]. As an intrinsic effect, altermagnetism was also predicted to appear in the parent cuprate La2CuO4 of a high-temperature superconductor [[54](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib54)] and recently also suggested to appear in the strongly correlated CuAg(SO4)2 [[153](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib153)], see also [[154](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib154)]. Intrinsic altermagnetism was also shown to be useful for topological superconductivity [[155](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib155)], spin-polarized -wave superconductivity [[156](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib156)], and strained-induced spin-triplet superconductivity [[131](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib131)], while its emergence was recently discussed in Sr2RuO4 [[157](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib157), [158](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib158)].

On a parallel front, hybrid systems formed by coupling unconventional magnets and superconductors have also received an enormous interest, originating a plethora of novel phenomena with fundamental and applied prospects. For instance, under generic grounds, it was shown that unconventional magnets not only induce a spin-singlet to spin-triplet conversion but also transfer their parity, generating superconducting correlations with spin-triplet symmetry and higher angular momentum [[159](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib159), [160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)]; this unveils the fundamental role of unconventional magnetism in superconductors; see also Refs.[[156](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib156), [161](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib161), [162](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib162), [163](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib163), [164](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib164), [165](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib165), [131](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib131)]. Moreover, in the simplest superconducting junction, when an AM is coupled to a superconductor, the reflection of an incident electron into a hole known as Andreev reflection (AR) was shown to strongly depend on the crystal orientation and the spin-splitting [[166](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib166), [167](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib167), [168](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib168), [169](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib169), [170](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib170), [171](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib171), [172](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib172)]; crossed ARs have also been studied in AM-superconductor-AM junctions [[173](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib173), [174](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib174)]. There also exist preliminary theoretical work on ARs in -wave magnet-superconductor junctions [[168](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib168)], with predictions of even zero-bias peaks [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)]. We note that the dependence of ARs on the transverse momentum originates the appearance of Andreev bound states (ABSs) that strongly disperse with such momentum, shown for superconducting junctions with -wave AMs and -wave magnets [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)]. Very recently, it was reported a single experimental study on the AR in AMs, which involved a planar junction between an indium electrode and MnTe altermagnetic candidate [[175](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib175)]. Since a finite AR in the unconventional magnet of a NS junction is directly related to the induced superconducting correlations in the unconventional magnets [[15](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib15), [160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)], we conclude that unconventional magnetism strongly affects the proximity effect [[176](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib176)]. The role of potential impurities in AMs was recently also studied [[177](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib177)], reporting impurity-induced local sign change of the order parameter and highly tunable spin-dependent tunneling that can be useful for quantum information processing.

The impact of unconventional magnetism was also investigated in junctions formed by two superconductors coupled via an unconventional magnet in the form of superconductor-unconventional magnet-superconductor Josephson junctions (JJs), thus allowing to explore the Josephson effect [[178](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib178)]. In JJs, ARs at both interfaces lead to the formation of ABSs, which become dependent on the superconducting phase difference that allows them to carry a dissipationaless supercurrent and determine the Josephson effect [[179](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib179), [180](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib180), [181](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib181), [182](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib182), [183](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib183), [184](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib184), [185](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib185), [186](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib186)]; see also Refs.  [[187](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib187), [188](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib188), [189](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib189), [190](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib190), [191](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib191), [192](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib192), [193](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib193), [194](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib194), [195](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib195), [196](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib196)]. In Josephson junctions based on -wave AMs and spin-singlet -wave superconductors, it was shown that altermagnetism induces in the free energy oscillations [[197](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib197), [198](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib198), [199](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib199), [200](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib200), [201](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib201), [160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160), [172](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib172), [202](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib202)] and oscillations away from with double degeneracy [[200](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib200), [160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)], which result from the strong influence of altermagnetism on the emergent ABSs. The - transitions were also predicted in altermagnet-based Josephson junctions formed by spin-singlet and spin-triplet superconductors [[203](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib203)]. For transitions in Josephson junctions without AMs, see Refs. [[204](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib204), [205](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib205), [206](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib206), [207](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib207), [181](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib181)]. The nontrivial features induced by altermagnetism in the free energy and ABSs induce anomalous features in the current-phase curves, involving the contribution from multiple harmonics of the superconducting phase difference [[200](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib200), [160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)], presence of multiple nodes [[200](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib200)], tunable skewness [[201](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib201)], and unconventional Fraunhofer patterns [[199](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib199)].

Besides the intriguing Josephson phenomena, altermagnetism was also shown to be useful for realizing other emergent superconducting phenomena. For instance, it was predicted that altermagnetism can be used to engineer topological superconductivity [[155](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib155), [208](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib208), [209](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib209), [210](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib210), [163](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib163), [211](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib211), [212](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib212)], where Majorana states are found to appear with a zero net magnetization; similarly, Ref. [[164](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib164)] recently reported the realization of topological superconductivity by using -wave magnetism, while Ref. [[213](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib213)] suggested the design of Majorana flat bands. As in regular semiconductor-superconductor Majorana devices, AM-based heterostructures might be also susceptible to the formation to topologically trivial zero-energy ABSs [[214](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib214)], which can, however, be distinguished e. g., by Josephson measurements [[215](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib215), [216](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib216), [217](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib217), [218](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib218)]. For trivial ABSs in superconducting junctions, including Josephson junctions, we refer to Refs.  [[219](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib219)] and also to Refs.  [[220](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib220), [221](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib221), [222](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib222), [223](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib223), [224](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib224), [225](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib225), [226](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib226), [215](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib215), [227](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib227), [228](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib228), [229](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib229), [216](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib216), [230](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib230), [231](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib231), [232](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib232), [217](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib217), [233](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib233), [234](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib234), [235](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib235), [236](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib236), [237](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib237)]. Altermagnetism was also proposed as a key ingredient for bulk [[238](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib238), [145](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib145), [239](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib239)] and Josephson superconducting diode effects [[240](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib240), [241](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib241), [242](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib242), [243](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib243)], where bulk diodes can even achieve perfect efficiencies due to finite momentum states [[239](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib239)]. It was also uncovered that the perfect diode effect in [[239](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib239)] is related to topology, opening the possibility for realizing topologically protected superconducting diodes, before suggested in superconductor-semiconductor Majorana systems [[244](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib244), [245](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib245)]; see also [[246](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib246), [247](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib247), [248](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib248)] for the diode effect in topological insulators and Refs. [[249](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib249), [250](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib250), [251](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib251), [252](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib252), [253](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib253), [254](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib254), [255](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib255), [256](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib256), [257](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib257), [258](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib258), [259](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib259), [260](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib260), [261](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib261)] for other studies on superconducting diodes. It is worth noting that the peculiar spin-momentum locking of unconventional magnets enables a nontrivial light-matter coupling [[262](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib262), [263](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib263), [128](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib128)] that is able to induce spin-triplet states, e.g., by means of Floquet engineering [[263](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib263), [264](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib264)], and control the spin magnetization [[262](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib262)]. We lastly note that AMs have recently been explored for realizing the magnetoelectric effect [[265](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib265), [266](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib266)], where a spin response is generated by an applied current and is relevant for superconducting spintronics. Thus, despite the recent studies on the interplay between unconventional magnets and superconductivity, the field has already seen an enormous and rapid progress, which reflects the importance of the field and believe that the advances will motivate experiments soon.

In this work, we aim at reviewing the recent progress on superconducting phenomena in systems formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors, with a particular attention on the low-energy models and their theoretical predictions. We first in Section [II](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2 "II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets") introduce unconventional magnetism, including even- and odd-parity magnets, how they are often modelled using minimal models, and their main properties. We then in Section [III](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3 "III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets") discuss the impact of superconductivity and unconventional magnetism, highlighting the possible superconducting symmetries that can emerge due to their combination in a hybrid system. In this part, we also address the Andreev reflection, proximity effect, and inverse proximity effect. In Section [IV](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4 "IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"), we focus on the Josephson effect and comment on how to model Josephson junctions, the formation of ABSs, the current-phase curves, induced correlations, and Josephson diode effects. In Section [V](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S5 "V Experimental advances ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"), we discuss the recent experimental advanced in unconventional magnets in the normal state and the single experiment involving superconductors. Our conclusions are presented in [VI](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S6 "VI Conclusions and outlook ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"), where we also remark possible future research directions driven by the interplay between unconventional magnetism and superconductivity.

This review does not intend to cover all the important advances in the field of unconventional magnetism and superconductivity. There are excellent reviews addressing distinct aspects of these areas and we therefore refer to those works. ## II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state

We start by discussing unconventional magnetism with even- and odd-parity magnetic orders which characterize e.g., -wave altermagnets (AMs) and -wave magnets. Altermagnetism is believed to be a third class of collinear magnetic phases, in addition to the well-known ferromagnets and antiferromagnets [[111](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib111), [46](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib46), [45](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib45), [106](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib106), [49](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib49), [275](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib275), [48](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib48), [276](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib276), [54](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib54), [53](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib53), [277](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib277), [61](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib61), [69](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib69), [51](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib51), [62](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib62), [65](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib65)]. The term ‘altermagnet’ was named after the anisotropic magnetization that ‘alternates’ direction in momentum space. The study on this state can be traced back to a series of discoveries of unconventional magnetism before the name was given, such as in the momentum-dependent spin split bands with antiferromagnetic order [[111](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib111), [46](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib46), [106](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib106), [48](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib48), [92](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib92)], the crystal Hall effect [[49](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib49)], the -paired spin-valley locking in antiferromagnets [[50](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib50)], or in the ferromagnetic response in antiferromagnets [[276](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib276)].

To understand the properties of AMs, we first review some characteristics of ferromagnets and antiferromagnets since AMs share common features with them, see Figs. [1](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S1.F1 "Figure 1 ‣ I Introduction ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets") and [2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.F2 "Figure 2 ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"). For ferromagnets, the exchange field induces a majority spin state and a minority spin state for all lattice sites [Fig. [1](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S1.F1 "Figure 1 ‣ I Introduction ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a)], making the majority spin state more populated at the Fermi surface [Fig. [1](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S1.F1 "Figure 1 ‣ I Introduction ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(e) and Fig. [2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.F2 "Figure 2 ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(b)]; see also Fig. [2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.F2 "Figure 2 ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a), which shows the Fermi surface of a normal metal without spin splitting is shown for comparison. In some half-metal materials, the minority spin state can disappear at the Fermi surface which results in full polarization. Thus, ferromagnets possess a non-vanishing net macroscopic magnet moment [[32](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib32), [34](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib34)]. In Landau’s broken symmetry theory, ferromagnets can be described by a ferromagnetic order parameter: the exchange field [[32](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib32)]. Such an exchange field is isotropic in ferromagnets since the ferromagnetic state is invariant under a unitary lattice symmetry. Another type of collinear magnets are antiferromagnets [[32](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib32), [34](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib34)], which has an alternating spin polarization in real space with neighboring sites possessing different spin Fig. [1](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S1.F1 "Figure 1 ‣ I Introduction ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(b). Thus, antiferromagnets are invariant under a unitary lattice translation or inversion symmetries [[31](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib31), [32](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib32), [33](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib33), [34](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib34)]. The spin degeneracy of an antiferromagnet is not lifted as dictated by parity-time-inversion () symmetry [Fig. [1](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S1.F1 "Figure 1 ‣ I Introduction ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(f)].

Based on the above discussion, AMs are similar to ferromagnets because both of them have a spin splitting of energy bands and spin-polarized Fermi surfaces, see Figs. [1](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S1.F1 "Figure 1 ‣ I Introduction ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a,c) and [2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.F2 "Figure 2 ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(b,e,f,h). However, the spin states of AMs compensate each other and result in zero net magnetization, akin to what occurs in antiferromagnets but distinct from ferromagnets. As already pointed out, AMs exhibit an exchange field that is even in momentum (even-parity), which can posses -, -, -wave symmetries [Fig. [2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.F2 "Figure 2 ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(b,e,f,h)]. Unlike antiferromagnets, the Kramers degeneracy in AMs is lifted because the opposite-spin sublattices can not map onto each other by a translation or inversion but are connected by a real-space rotation transformation [[53](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib53)], as shown in Fig. [1](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S1.F1 "Figure 1 ‣ I Introduction ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(c,g). In AMs, is broken by the combined lattice geometry and spin ordering [[53](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib53)]. Furthermore, an important property of AMs is that the spin-splitting field does not originate from relativistic effects, which is distinct from relativistically spin-orbit coupling [[58](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib58), [59](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib59)].For this reason, the spin-splitting field in AMs acquire larger values, e. g., reaching the order of  eV [[53](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib53)]. In relativistically spin-orbit coupling systems, such as semiconductors with Rashba spin-orbit couplings, it requires heavy element to produce large spin-splitting but their values are not very large [[59](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib59), [58](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib58), [278](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib278)]. In contrast, AMs have advantages in providing significant spin-splitting field in lighter compounds based on e.g., Fe and Mn. Even though the field is still developing, there have already been a large number of theoretical and experimental studies addressing AMs and their properties; see e. g., Refs. [[77](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib77), [111](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib111), [45](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib45), [106](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib106), [49](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib49), [54](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib54), [70](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib70), [68](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib68), [67](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib67)] for some previous experiments and Section [V](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S5 "V Experimental advances ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets") for more details on the experimental advances. In terms of theoretical developments in the normal state, AMs have been proposed to realize ultrafast THz switching devices with no stray fields and with low damping spin currents [[279](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib279), [280](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib280), [281](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib281)] and they have also were suggested to generate a giant tunneling magnetoresistance effect [[282](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib282)]. Moreover, AMs were shown to be useful for anomalous Hall effects [[49](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib49), [92](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib92), [85](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib85), [75](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib75), [107](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib107), [132](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib132)], including a skyrmion Hall effect [[283](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib283)], as well as for promoting high harmonic generation [[284](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib284)]. Other studies of AMs involved impurity-induced Friedel oscillations in the local density of states [[139](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib139)], strain-induced spin splitting [[285](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib285), [136](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib136)], spin splitting Nernst effect [[113](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib113), [120](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib120)], higher-order topological state [[123](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib123)], field-sensitive dislocation bound states [[286](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib286)], parity anomaly in weak topological insulators [[287](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib287)], bilayer stacking ferromagnets with antiferromagnet coupling [[288](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib288)], in heavy fermions systems [[289](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib289)], a Landau theory of altermagnetism [[121](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib121)], and spin currents [[91](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib91), [117](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib117), [134](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib134), [135](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib135), [285](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib285), [91](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib91), [290](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib290)]; see also Refs. [[61](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib61), [62](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib62), [52](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib52), [51](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib51)] for a more detailed discussion of the advances on AMs in the normal state. It is clear that the number of candidate altermagnetic materials is now rapidly growing [[53](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib53), [54](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib54), [61](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib61), [62](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib62), [69](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib69), [69](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib69), [67](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib67), [80](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib80), [291](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib291), [292](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib292), [293](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib293)], and all the advances support the benefits of AMs for potential spintronic applications.

After the prediction and discovery of altermagnetism, the field moved quickly to the study of odd-parity unconventional magnets, which can exhibit a magnetic order with and -wave symmetries [[47](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib47)]. In the case of -wave unconventional magnets, they are both noncollinear and noncoplanar magnets with preserved time-reversal symmetry and broken inversion symmetry [[57](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib57), [56](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib56)]. More precisely, -wave unconventional magnets are protected by the combination of the time-reversal operation () and a translation of half the unit cell () [[56](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib56)]. To visualize some preliminary properties of -wave magnets without delving into the specific models, in Figs. [1](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S1.F1 "Figure 1 ‣ I Introduction ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(d) we show an schematic illustration of the -wave magnet lattice based on the effective model of Ref. [[57](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib57)], induced by the spin-rotational structure along one direction, while Figs. [1](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S1.F1 "Figure 1 ‣ I Introduction ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(h) shows the energy dispersion for the same model but without the isotropic sd coupling between between a localized spins and itinerant electrons discussed in [[57](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib57)]; later on we will deepen the discussion of models and their properties. In Figs. [2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.F2 "Figure 2 ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(c,d,g), we also depict the Fermi surfaces of -wave magnets, while in Figs. [2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.F2 "Figure 2 ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(g) of a -wave magnet. In terms of materials for odd-parity magnets, Ref. [[56](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib56)] predicted Mn3GaN and CeNiAsO as candidate materials for -wave magnetism but their experimental verification is still an open task. The interest in -wave magnets has recently also attracted more attention, with studies addressing Friedel oscillations in the local density of states [[139](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib139)], transverse spin currents  [[294](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib294)], linear and nonlinear conductivities [[140](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib140)], spin-current diode effect [[117](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib117)], and highly efficient non-relativistic Edelstein effect [[295](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib295)].

Most of the theoretical advances on both AMs and -wave magnets have employed minimal models that capture the main properties of both unconventional magnets. Due to the relevance of these models for the advance of the field and for understanding most of the phenomena in unconventional magnets, we discuss them in the next subsection.

At this point, we comment on the proper use of these Hamiltonians to model unconventional magnets. For -wave AMs, the Hamiltonians given in Eq.([7](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.E7 "In II.1 Minimal models for understanding unconventional magnetism ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")) and ([9](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.E9 "In II.1 Minimal models for understanding unconventional magnetism ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")) provide similar bulk information, such as the dispersion and their magnetic splitting near the Fermi level. On the other hand, the momentum dependent spin-splitting may affect transport in junctions or systems with edge states, and in this case one has to be careful when using the real space or continuum descriptions of unconventional magnets. This problem becomes important when addressing magnetic properties of the edge states or the spin-transport in junctions because local spin structure at the edge/interface may affect them. For instance, this is relevant when considering the particular [100] edge, the magnetic moments at the edge depend on the termination of the system. To consider the local spin-structure in continuum model, magnetic boundary conditions are required, which in principle involve distinct conditions for up- and the down-spins. A similar discussion applies to the use of -wave magnets. To summarize, we have reviewed the minimal models of unconventional magnets. The effective Hamiltonians in the continuum are given by Eqs. ([1](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.E1 "In II.1 Minimal models for understanding unconventional magnetism ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")) while in the tight-binding description is given by Eqs. ([8](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.E8 "In II.1 Minimal models for understanding unconventional magnetism ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")). While these models have been broadly used for investigating superconductivity involving unconventional magnets, discussed in Sections [III](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3 "III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets") and [IV](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4 "IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"), we note that it would be interesting to adopt the microscopic models in the form of Eqs. ([9](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.E9 "In II.1 Minimal models for understanding unconventional magnetism ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")) and ([10](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.E10 "In II.1 Minimal models for understanding unconventional magnetism ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")) in future studies of transport phenomena.

### II.2 Topological phases in unconventional magnets

The past two decades have witnessed significant progress in topological materials, with an enormous focus on systems with spin-orbit coupling. In this regard, unconventional magnets provide an alternative ground to realize functional topological materials. Since the field is still developing [[53](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib53), [209](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib209)], most of the studies are theoretical but experimental activity will very likely be reported soon. By now, it has already been predicted that it is possible to realize topological nontrivial unconventional magnets [[209](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib209), [307](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib307), [308](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib308), [309](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib309), [310](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib310), [311](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib311), [312](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib312), [57](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib57), [313](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib313), [286](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib286), [314](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib314), [51](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib51)], efforts that also suggest to engineer topological states by combing unconventional magnets with topological materials.

For intrinsic altermagnetic materials, relativistic spin-orbit coupling, which generally exists in actual crystal environment or induced by external inversion symmetry breaking [[58](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib58), [59](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib59)], are crucial for producing topological phases. Several examples are related to the spin-degenerate nodal lines in the Brillouin zone. In Ref. [[312](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib312), [51](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib51)], the authors showed that the nodal lines enabled by spin-orbit coupling give rise to pinch points in altermagnetic metals. Such pinch points behave as single or double type-II Weyl nodes due to a nontrivial Berry curvature around them and thus can be viewed as topological objects. Consequently, a topological transition occurs from altermagnetic to ferromagnetic phases driven by an external field. Another representative example is the altermagnetic Weyl semimetal CrSb [[313](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib313)], where the splitting of the non-relativistic nodal plane by the relativistic spin-orbit coupling leads to the emergence of pairs of Weyl points. For a two-dimensional AM, the band structure normally has spin-polarized Dirac points but the presence of spin-orbit coupling can gap out the Dirac points, resulting in the formation of the first-order topological insulator [[309](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib309), [308](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib308)]. The topological phases in AMs can even be tuned by the strength and directions of an applied external magnetic field combined with spin-orbit coupling, see Ref. [[315](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib315)]. Moreover, when AMs are combined with first-order topological insulators, Refs. [[209](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib209), [123](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib123)] showed that it is possible to induce high-order topological insulator phases. Apart from these studies, it is important to remark that among the most interesting phenomena associated with the topological nature of AMs are the anomalous Hall effect and its thermal counterpart (known as anomalous Nernst effect) reported in Refs. [[49](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib49), [316](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib316), [85](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib85), [87](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib87), [317](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib317)]. The authors showed that these Hall phases occur due to nontrivial berry curvatures induced by broken and symmetries in AMs; here, , and represent the time-reversal, space inversion, and translation symmetries. The intriguing role of the Berry curvature was recently taken further in Ref. [[318](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib318)], which showed that quantum geometry, involving the Berry curvature and quantum metric [[319](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib319)], can induce a nonlinear third-order response in planar AMs. Quantum geometry has recently been generalized to multiband systems [[320](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib320)], which was already applied to explore normal state systems [[321](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib321)] and also superconductors [[322](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib322)]. Given that AMs are in general multiband [Eq. ([9](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.E9 "In II.1 Minimal models for understanding unconventional magnetism ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"))], we anticipate that investigating quantum geometry in AMs will uncover new physics at the intersection of geometry, topology, and altermagnetism.

In relation to topological phases based on -wave magnets, less number of works have been reported in the normal state [[323](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib323), [57](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib57)] since the field is still in its infancy. Ref. [[323](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib323)] shows that a hybrid system formed by a -wave magnet and a metal with orbital degree of freedom can realize a topological insulator without spin-orbit interaction. Furthermore, by considering momentum-dependent sd-coupling in -wave magnets, Ref. [[57](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib57)] demonstrated that it is possible to induce nontrivial topology. We hope that these studies will encourage the community to further expand the topology of -wave magnets.

By now, it is well accepted that unconventional magnets provide promising opportunities for engineering topological phases without relaying on relativistic spin-orbit coupling in contrast to the arena offered by semiconductors [[58](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib58), [59](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib59)]. Of interest is also that unconventional magnetism can also enhance the often small relativistic spin-orbit coupling, thus allowing the possibility to boost topological order. Another important route is to combine the characteristic magnetic order of unconventional magnets with other topological phases, e. g., in the form of heterostructures, a situation that can lead to induced emergent phases with entirely new functionalities. Motivated by these possibilities, in the next section, we focus on the interplay between unconventional magnetism and superconductivity, with a broader goal to identify novel emergent phenomena.

### III.1 Intrinsic superconductivity in unconventional magnets

Most of the studies that addressed intrinsic superconductivity in unconventional magnets focused on the coexistence of superconductivity and altermagnetism in a single material as well as the possible generation of superconductivity by spin fluctuations in AMs. One of the initial works investigated the formation of superconductivity in a -wave AM under the presence of Rashba spin-orbit coupling (SOC) [[155](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib155)] since it naturally appears during the growing process of AMs on substrates [[336](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib336)]. In particular, the authors consider an extended attractive Hubbard interaction allowing for both spin-singlet - and equal spin-triplet -wave pairing channels, where their respective pair potentials are found within a self-consistent approach by an expression similar to Eq. ([11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.E11 "In III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")) in the -wave AM modelled by the third expression of Eqs. ([8](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.E8 "In II.1 Minimal models for understanding unconventional magnetism ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")) under Rashba SOC. The system was then shown to host a mixture of spin-singlet -wave and spin-triplet -wave superconductivity due to the simultaneous effect of breaking time-reversal symmetry by altermagnetism and inversion symmetry by SOC [[155](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib155)]. Another key aspect of this study is that it reports dominant -wave superconductivity when the combined action of time-reversal and four-fold rotational around the axis symmetries is preserved [[155](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib155)]; this symmetry combination is also preserved in AMs and uncovers the intriguing role of -wave altermagnetism on the type of emergent superconductivity. In an almost parallel study, superconductivity and altermagnetism was addressed in a system with itinerant electrons and magnetic sites but without SOC [[156](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib156)], where the onsite exchange interaction between itinerant and localized spins induces a spin splitting, expected in AMs, and is also responsible for an electron-magnon coupling due to fluctuations in the localized spins. Interestingly, Ref. [[156](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib156)] found that, while nonmagnetic sites are essential for -wave altermagnetism, a symmetry also exhibited by the splitting of magnon bands, the electron-magnon coupling gives rise to electron-electron interactions (as the one leading to Eq. ([11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.E11 "In III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"))) but mediated by two magnons; this then produces a dominant equal spin-triplet -wave superconductivity with sizeable spin polarization determined by in Eq. ([16](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.E16 "In III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")), perhaps already anticipated in Ref. [[141](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib141)]. This electron-magnon induced superconductivity was then also confirmed under many-body effects [[324](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib324)], carried out within the strong-coupling approach of the Eliashberg theory [[337](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib337), [338](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib338)]. Within the weak coupling limit, the spin-triplet odd-momentum superconducting state can be dominant by the electron-phonon coupling [[339](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib339)].

In a subsequent study, the role of magnetic exchange interactions in AMs was further explored as a mechanism to drive superconductivity [[144](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib144)], where the chosen system involved a multiorbital model on a square-octagon lattice. By allowing all (charge, spin, and pairing) mean-field channels [[144](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib144)], distinct phases appear, such as the coexistence of altermagnetism and superconductivity having a mixture of spin-singlet -wave and mixed spin-triplet -wave as well as a -type pair-density wave due to the Fermi surface nesting, thus reflecting the intriguing role of altermagnetism for realizing nontrivial states. Moreover, in a study earlier than Refs. [[324](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib324), [144](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib144)], it was shown that finite momentum superconductivity can naturally appear in -wave AMs with spin-singlet -wave superconductivity even in the absence of net magnetization, as long as their nodes coincide; here, intrinsic superconductivity is due to an effective nearest-neighbor attraction for spin-singlet pairing, where the pair potential is found from an equation similar to Eq. ([11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.E11 "In III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")) but with the momentum decomposition allowing for a finite center-of-mass momentum of Cooper pairs; see also Refs. [[145](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib145), [146](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib146), [239](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib239), [147](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib147), [161](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib161)] for other theoretical studies supporting the appearance of finite momentum superconductivity in AMs. Another studied aspect of altermagnetism is its potential for modifying the parity symmetry, which was shown in Ref. [[325](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib325)] with the appearance of spin-triplet -wave superconductivity in -wave AMs with spin-singlet and spin-triplet pair potentials. Besides AMs, superconductivity was very recently studied in -wave magnets taking into account a pair potential from the simplest electron-phonon mediated interaction similar to Eq. ([11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.E11 "In III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")), which then was shown to produce spin-singlet -wave and equal spin-triplet -wave superconductivity [[162](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib162)]. Moreover, Ref. [[340](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib340)] recently reported a systematic approach to construct superconducting order parameters within the framework of spin space groups, which describe the symmetry of unconventional magnets. Taking altogether, the theoretical advances on intrinsic superconductivity in unconventional magnetism uncovered the potential of unconventional magnets for hosting novel superconducting phases.

### III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors

Having discussed the effect of unconventional magnetism on the superconducting pair symmetries, in this part we address the emergent phenomena when unconventional magnets are placed in contact with a superconductor. In particular, we focus on NS hybrid junctions where N represents a normal state material, which can be any normal metal or unconventional magnet, while S denotes a superconductor, as schematically shown in Fig. [7](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F7 "Figure 7 ‣ III.2 Possible superconducting pair correlations due to unconventional magnetism ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a). NS junctions are the simplest superconducting junctions that permit us to analyze fundamental superconducting phenomena due to the combination of unconventional magnetism, superconductivity, and the breaking of spatial translation at the junction’s interface.

Upon appropriate modifications of the profile of the pair potential, it is also possible to model finite N and S regions in superconducting junctions, see e. g., Refs. [[354](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib354), [375](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib375), [360](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib360), [230](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib230), [364](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib364), [246](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib246), [377](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib377), [247](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib247), [200](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib200)]. The total solutions would then need to comply with the continuity of wavefunctions at the respective interfaces, such as at in Fig. [7](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F7 "Figure 7 ‣ III.2 Possible superconducting pair correlations due to unconventional magnetism ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a). Another possibility to model NS junctions with finite N and S regions is to carry out a tight-binding discretization of the BdG Hamiltonian within a tunneling Hamiltonian approach [[223](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib223), [196](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib196), [235](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib235), [183](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib183), [233](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib233), [237](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib237), [17](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib17)], thus allowing to explore finite size effects. Whenever necessary, we will refer to the type of approach used to model superconducting junctions, see also Refs. [[330](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib330), [378](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib378), [379](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib379), [380](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib380)].

The right moving electron from N can be also transmitted into S as a quasielectron or quasihole, processes known as normal transmissions and Andreev transmissions, respectively. When scattering occurs at energies within the superconducting gap, the AR involves the transfer of a Cooper pair into S [[376](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib376)], sketched in Fig. [7](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F7 "Figure 7 ‣ III.2 Possible superconducting pair correlations due to unconventional magnetism ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a). The Andreev reflection is perhaps the most fundamental effect in superconducting junctions and does not have any analog in normal state heterostructures [[381](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib381), [382](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib382), [376](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib376)]. Such a behavior can be understood by using symmetry arguments: Under a mirror reflection with respect to the plane, the orbital part of the -wave AM changes its sign so that and are connected via mirror reflection. After the sum of all transverse channels with positive and negative , become the same with . On the other hand, the orbital part of the -wave AM has no sign change under the mirror operation with respect to the plane, leading to a finite spin polarization . This conductance behavior is thus different from what occurs when N is a ferromagnet but it is similar when N is a normal metal [Fig. [7](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F7 "Figure 7 ‣ III.2 Possible superconducting pair correlations due to unconventional magnetism ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(c)], pointing out an intriguing difference of AMs with respect to ferromagnets despite both breaking time-reversal symmetry. The reason for this behavior is that there are no available Fermi surfaces corresponding to ARs for quasiparticles with large transverse momentum. The discussed effect was first predicted in Ref. [[168](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib168)] and recently also confirmed in Ref.[[162](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib162)].
