Thus, unconventional magnets affect the charge conductance in NS junctions.

So far we have assumed that the unconventional magnet is semi-infinite and it is thus natural to wonder what happens to the conductance when the unconventional magnet has a finite length. These ideas were explored in Refs. [[167](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib167), [166](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib166), [169](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib169), [170](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib170), [172](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib172)] which involved AMs but not -wave magnets. To understand the conductance features in superconducting junctions with AMs of finite length, it is important to understand the underlying properties of N1N2S junctions, where N1 and S are semi-infinite normal and superconducting regions, while N2 is a finite normal region. In this case, an incident electron from N1 gets transmitted to N2, which then experiences confinement effects due to the finite length of N2 and also Andreev reflections at the N2S interface [[230](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib230)]. The interplay of confinement and ARs give rise to the formation of discrete states within the superconducting gap having electron and hole characters, also known as Andreev bound states (ABSs). This phenomenon already appears when N2 is just a normal metal, where ABSs have been revealed to produce conductance features that help identify the type of superconductor [[230](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib230)]. In the case of N1N2S junctions where N1 and S are a semi-infinite normal metal and a spin-singlet -wave superconductor, Ref. [[167](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib167)] predicted that ABSs appear and can even produce zero-bias peaks for -wave AMs [Fig. [10](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F10 "Figure 10 ‣ III.3.2 Andreev reflections and Andreev bound states ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")]; this suggests a strong dependence of conductance on the altermagnetic orientation. Moreover, in a similar type of N1N2S junction, Ref. [[169](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib169)] found that a special type of AR occurs, known as specular AR when the reflection angle is inverted with respect to the angle of incidence [[387](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib387)], which induces a positive nonlocal conductance and can be useful for realizing Cooper pair splitters.

Later, Ref. [[172](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib172)] explored conductance and ABSs in N1N2S junctions with N2 being a -wave AM and S being a -wave superconductor, a system motivated by the need to understand the impact of the -wave nature in both materials; the ABSs in Ref. [[172](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib172)] are referred to as de Gennes and Saint-James states. Interestingly, while the -wave nature of AMs induces ABSs already when S is a conventional spin-singlet -wave superconductor [[167](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib167)], having a -wave superconductor affects the levels around zero energy which then produce distinct features in the tunneling conductance, see Fig. [10](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F10 "Figure 10 ‣ III.3.2 Andreev reflections and Andreev bound states ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a-d). For a N2 finite region being a -wave AM, the tunneling conductance develops a zero-bias peak due to the formation of zero-energy ABSs; this effect occurs because the spin-split bands in -wave AMs enhance the mismatch between electron and hole wave vectors, resulting in a sizable phase accumulation in the process of sequential NRs and ARs inside the altermagnetic region N2; these zero-bias peaks originate due to confinement effects in the finite region N2 [[230](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib230)]. In contrast, for a N2 finite region being a -wave AM, ABSs with a different profile appear and lead to a V-shape profile of the tunneling conductance around zero energy, but with a finite value at zero energy, see Fig. [10](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F10 "Figure 10 ‣ III.3.2 Andreev reflections and Andreev bound states ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(c,d). It is important to notice that other more recent works have also explored Andreev transport in modified junctions based on AMs [[173](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib173), [174](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib174)] and -wave magnets -wave [[388](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib388)], which have enabled the inspection of nonlocal Andreev reflections also known as crossed Andreev reflections [[389](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib389), [376](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib376)]. While these studies indeed reveal the intriguing impact of unconventional magnetism in superconducting systems, there are still phenomena that need to be explored such as crossed ARs [[173](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib173)] and also Andreev physics in -wave magnets [[388](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib388)] as well as in superconducting junctions with higher momentum unconventional magnets. The so far reported strong dependence of the ABSs and their conductance signatures in junctions with -wave altermagnetism and superconductivity unveils novel superconducting phenomena that can be further exploited for the design of e.g., Andreev qubits [[390](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib390), [391](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib391), [392](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib392)], see also Refs. [[21](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib21), [23](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib23)].

#### III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect

In the previous part, we have seen that Andreev processes in superconducting junctions are able to carry information about the superconductor deep into a non-superconducting unconventional magnet material when placed in very close proximity. We have shown that the carried information strongly depends on the properties of both the unconventional magnet and superconductor, raising a natural question about the nature of superconductivity when combining unconventional magnets and superconductors in the form of hybrid junctions. This question was partially addressed in Subsection [III.2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.SS2 "III.2 Possible superconducting pair correlations due to unconventional magnetism ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"), where we showed that distinct types of superconducting correlations emerge when an entire two-dimensional unconventional magnet has homogeneous superconductivity, provided spatial invariance is preserved. However, in junctions, such as those where ARs have been studied and where spatial invariance is broken, the nature of superconductivity still remains unknown and we plan to study it in this part.

For simplicity, let us first point out some basic features about superconducting correlations in NS junctions located at and with a pair potential ; here N and S are semi-infinite regions of a normal metal and a conventional superconductor, respectively. The superconducting correlations can then be obtained from the anomalous part of the Nambu Green’s function associated with the BdG Hamiltonian of the system, as discussed in Subsection [III.2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.SS2 "III.2 Possible superconducting pair correlations due to unconventional magnetism ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"); since momentum along is not a good quantum number, depends on two spatial coordinates [[9](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib9), [15](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib15), [342](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib342), [17](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib17)]. For NS junctions, it is useful to calculate the Nambu Green’s function by using scattering states [[394](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib394), [180](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib180), [395](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib395), [360](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib360), [15](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib15)], so that the semi-infinite nature of N and S are taken into account. Alternatively, one can use a recursive Green’s function approach within a tight-binding description, also proven useful for calculating the Green’s function of semi-infinite superconducting systems [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160), [393](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib393)]. Under general conditions, even though the pair potential in N is zero, it is possible to induce a nonzero pair amplitude in N, with a characteristic length [[396](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib396), [397](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib397)], which at zero energy is kept all the way to infinity and signals the superconducting coherence; at finite temperatures, one recovers , after doing an appropriate analytic continuation . Analogously, an Andreev reflected hole has the opposite velocity at zero energy and traces the same phase in a phase coherence fashion. Both the induced pair amplitude in N and the Andreev reflections have been shown to be directly related to each other and to be at the core of what is known as the superconducting *proximity effect* [[398](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib398), [176](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib176), [354](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib354), [375](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib375), [15](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib15)], where the part of N closest to S acquires superconducting correlations, see light green region in N of the bottom panel of Fig. [7](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F7 "Figure 7 ‣ III.2 Possible superconducting pair correlations due to unconventional magnetism ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a). Furthermore, in the same way as the N region gets affected by the superconductor, the region of S closest to N over a range also suffers changes intimately connected to the nature of N. For instance, given that S can be a conventional spin-singlet s-wave superconductor, it is possible to induce superconducting correlations with a distinct symmetry, which gives rise to an effect known as the *inverse proximity effect*; this effect has been mostly studied when N is a magnetic material which then induces a magnetic moment in the superconductor [[399](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib399), [396](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib396), [400](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib400), [401](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib401)] but recently also addressed under the presence of ABSs [[402](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib402)]. The inverse proximity effect is depicted by a blue-green region in S of the bottom panel of Fig. [7](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F7 "Figure 7 ‣ III.2 Possible superconducting pair correlations due to unconventional magnetism ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a).

To understand the proximity effect and the inverse proximity effect in NS junctions formed by unconventional magnets, in what follows we discuss the emergent pair amplitudes from Ref. [[393](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib393)] obtained for semi-infinite unconventional magnets and semi-infinite spin-singlet -wave superconductors. We consider a NS junction along located at , such that the pair potential is finite only in S, ; to model N and S, a tight-binding (TB) description of the unconventional magnets and superconductors is taken with an appropriate discretization along but keeping a good quantum number, as discussed in Ref. [[393](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib393)], see also Section [III](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3 "III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"). Here, within a TB representation, we remind that the strength of the exchange fields for a ferromagnet, -wave AM, -wave AM, -wave magnet, and -wave magnet are denoted by , , , and , respectively; see Subsection [II.1](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.SS1 "II.1 Minimal models for understanding unconventional magnetism ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"). Then, the pair amplitudes are found within a recursive Green’s function approach as discussed in Ref. [[393](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib393)]. Under general circumstances, NS junctions formed by unconventional magnets host four pair symmetries, which include the ESE, OSO, ETO, and OTE classes discussed in Subsection [III.2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.SS2 "III.2 Possible superconducting pair correlations due to unconventional magnetism ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"), where the first, second, and third capital letters represent the even (odd) symmetry of frequency, spin, and momentum parity, respectively. Moreover, the main role of the interface in NS junctions is that it breaks the spatial invariance, a mechanism that leads to the coexistence of even- and odd-parity states even when the bulk of S is a conventional spin-singlet -wave parity [[15](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib15)]. Thus, here we also expect four pair symmetry classes due to the interplay of unconventional magnetism and breaking of spatial invariance at the NS interface. In Fig. [11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F11 "Figure 11 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"), we show the absolute value of the local pair amplitudes as a function of space at lowest frequency and fixed for NS junctions with N being either a ferromagnet, a -wave AM, or a -wave magnet; here and correspond to N and S, respectively. In Fig. [11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F11 "Figure 11 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(d-f), we also plot the square absolute value of the pair amplitudes of panels Fig. [11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F11 "Figure 11 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a-c) integrated in the transverse momentum . For completeness, in Fig. [11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F11 "Figure 11 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(g-i) we also present the zero-energy electronic LDOS and local spin density along integrated in . Thus, the absence of OTE in NS junctions with -wave AMs is accompanied by the absence of spin density along , see Fig. [11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F11 "Figure 11 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(h). For NS junctions with -wave magnets, an odd-parity symmetry in restricts the formation of OTE as for -wave AMs, while ESE is induced into N in an oscillatory decaying fashion that is distinct to what happens in -wave magnets, see Fig. [11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F11 "Figure 11 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(c,f). In this case, the LDOS in N develops weak oscillations with the same periodicity as the ESE pair amplitude and decays from the interface into S, while vanishing local spin density is obtained in NS junctions with both types of -wave magnets, see Fig. [11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F11 "Figure 11 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(i). In all cases discussed here, the vanishing LDOS deep in S already indicates the conventional nature of the parent superconductor, which exhibits a U-shaped LDOS and is independent of the magnetic nature of N. We can therefore see that the proximity effect in NS junctions based on unconventional magnets is governed by penetration lengths in the unconventional magnets that are entirely associated to their type of magnetic nature. Moreover, while a clear inverse proximity effect is predicted in -wave AMs, the preliminary findings of Ref. [[393](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib393)] suggests vanishing values for the local amplitudes in -wave AMs and -wave magnets.

Further insights on the inverse proximity effect can be obtained from Fig. [12](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F12 "Figure 12 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"), where we show the LDOS () and local spin density () integrated over inside S but very close to the interface of a NS junction. Since it is known that the inverse proximity effect is sensitive to the appearance of ABSs [[402](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib402)], we consider a finite length N region made of a magnetic material, which is expected to host ABSs due to confinement in N [[223](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib223), [216](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib216), [230](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib230), [217](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib217)]. One of the main features is that LDOS exhibits subgap peaks representing the emergence of ABSs, whose position however depends on the magnetic order and chemical potential, see Fig. [12](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F12 "Figure 12 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets") and also insets. Another interesting feature is that, while the LDOS is always finite and develops a U-shape profile, the local spin density develops finite values only for the -wave AM and ferromagnet but vanishes otherwise. The negative value of the spin density is a result of having that is larger than , provided . This behavior holds even for a stronger chemical potential and exchange field, supporting the absence of induced local pair amplitudes that contribute to the inverse proximity effect in NS junctions formed by -wave AMs and -wave magnets, see insets. These results, however, do not rule out the formation of nonlocal superconducting correlations as contributing sources to the inverse proximity effect in such systems [[403](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib403)], but their relevance still remains unexplored. Having discussed the proximity effect and the inverse proximity effect in terms of emergent superconducting correlations, it is important to remark some points needed for adding more fundamental understanding of superconductivity in unconventional magnets. Thus, while a direct relationship is known to exist between the discussed proximity effects and Andreev processes, the method used to obtain Fig. [11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F11 "Figure 11 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets") does not allow to identify it; to discover such a relationship, the superconducting correlations need to be calculated by using a scattering Green’s function approach, which involves scattering states defined in terms of Andreev and normal processes [[394](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib394), [180](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib180), [395](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib395), [360](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib360), [15](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib15)]. Furthermore, the understanding of the proximity effect as well as the inverse proximity effect would enormously benefit from the investigation of superconducting correlations in hybrid systems with unconventional magnets under realistic conditions, such as the unavoidable finite size [[404](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib404), [237](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib237)] as well as the intrinsic multiple degrees of freedom [[405](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib405), [350](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib350), [406](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib406), [361](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib361), [342](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib342), [407](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib407)].

### III.4 Emergent superconducting phenomena in unconventional magnets

One particular aspect of combining unconventional magnetism with superconductivity is that it leads to novel phenomena even when considering conventional superconductors. One of the most fundamental consequences of such a combination was discussed in Subsection [III.2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.SS2 "III.2 Possible superconducting pair correlations due to unconventional magnetism ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets") and involves the realization of novel superconducting pair symmetries, where unconventional magnetism not only affects the spin symmetry but also the parity in momentum, see Table [2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.T2 "Table 2 ‣ III.1 Intrinsic superconductivity in unconventional magnets ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"). In this regard, spin-triplet Cooper pairs can be realized in AMs and also in -wave magnets [[159](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib159)], which, under appropriate material design, can pave the way for superconducting spintronics [[3](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib3), [4](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib4), [5](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib5), [6](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib6), [7](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib7), [8](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib8)] without net magnetization [[61](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib61), [408](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib408)]. Besides spin-triplet Cooper pairs, the interest in unconventional magnets has already led to interesting studies that demonstrate the utility of AMs for even more intriguing superconducting phenomena. Among the most salient examples, of fundamental and applied relevance, we highlight the utilization of -wave altermagnetism for realizing topological superconductivity [[155](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib155), [210](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib210), [208](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib208), [209](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib209), [163](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib163)], superconducting diodes [[239](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib239), [145](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib145), [238](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib238)], magnetoelectric effects [[265](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib265), [266](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib266)], and thermoelectric effects [[327](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib327), [326](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib326)], see also Fig. [13](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F13 "Figure 13 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"). These studies demonstrate the impact of unconventional magnetism for advancing the search of novel superconducting phenomena in distinct areas, an aspect that will very likely lead to useful quantum applications in the near future. In this part, we briefly review the four examples of novel superconducting effects highlighted above.

#### III.4.1 Topological superconductivity

Topological superconductivity is a topological phase of matter that is characterized by the formation of boundary states known as Majorana zero modes or simply as Majorana modes [[10](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib10), [11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib11), [17](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib17)]. The intrinsic spatial nonlocality and topological nature of Majorana states are useful for designing qubits that are robust against local sources of decoherence [[18](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib18), [22](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib22), [21](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib21), [24](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib24)], which highlights the enormous potential of topological superconductivity. In terms of ingredients for topological superconductivity, initial proposals showed that such a topological phase needs unconventional spin-triplet -wave superconductivity [[10](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib10), [11](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib11)], which is however scarce in nature [[63](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib63)]. By now, it is well-understood that topological superconductivity can be engineered by using common ingredients, such as spin-orbit coupling, conventional spin-singlet -wave superconductivity, and magnetism [[17](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib17), [12](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib12)]. In this case, the topological superconducting phase hosting Majorana modes emerges after a topological phase transition as the external magnetic field exceeds a critical value [[17](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib17)]. Following these ideas, several experiments have reported measurements with signatures that seem consistent with Majorana physics [[13](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib13), [274](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib274), [14](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib14)], although several studies have also challenged the interpretation of such results as they might come from trivial states and hence not related to Majorana modes [[222](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib222), [223](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib223), [219](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib219)]. Moreover, the topological phase transition, which is the key to identify the formation of the topological phase, has not been observed yet; in this regard, a recent study suggested that it can be measured by Raman spectroscopy [[409](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib409)], but still awaits experimental confirmation. Another concern in all these works is that the magnetism needed to reach the topological superconducting phase, coming from either a ferromagnet or external magnetic fields, is detrimental for conventional superconductivity e. g., due to Zeeman depairing effects. All these challenges suggest the need to explore other detection protocols and, most importantly, alternative materials with less detrimental effects for superconductivity.

With the advent of AMs, a new door opened in the field of topological superconductivity because such unconventional magnets exhibit a spin-splitting of energy bands like ferromagnets while maintaining zero net magnetization, thus being more friendly towards superconductivity. In this regard, topological superconductivity was initially addressed as an intrinsic phenomenon [[155](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib155)] by taking into account -wave altermagnetism and Rashba SOC with an extended attractive Hubbard interaction for spin-singlet and spin-triplet pairing channels. Ref. [[155](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib155)] found that altermagnetism is favorable for spin-triplet -wave superconductivity, which then can realize topological superconductivity with distinct types of Majorana modes, including chiral and helical propagating Majorana modes as well as localized Majorana corner modes. Interestingly, the combination of time-reversal symmetry and the four-fold rotation along the -axis, inherent to AMs, enforces the emergence of Majorana corner modes, thus unveiling the potential of altermagnetism for topological superconductivity and Majorana physics. Beyond intrinsic topological superconductivity, unconventional magnetism has shown to be promising for realizing Majorana physics in hybrid systems formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors. For instance, Majorana corner modes were predicted in Ref. [[210](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib210)] by simply coupling a conventional superconductor, a two-dimensional topological insulator and a AMs, where the Majorana states can be controlled by the direction of the Néel vector; see also Ref. [[208](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib208)] for a similar study by combining DIII topological superconductors and -wave AMs. The combination of AMs with conventional superconductors was more detailed addressed in Ref. [[209](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib209)], which predicted the realization of topological superconductivity without net magnetization in one and two dimensions with Majorana edge modes and Majorana chiral (and corner) modes, respectively. Of particular relevance is the realization of one-dimensional topological superconductivity by coupling a one-dimensional semiconductor to a -wave AM with conventional spin-singlet -wave superconductivity Ref. [[209](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib209)], see the top panel of Fig. [13](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F13 "Figure 13 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a). The one-dimensional hybrid model belongs to the BDI symmetry class, which has an integer topological invariant and realizes a topological phase when the exchange field when , where is the exchange field, the chemical potential in a tight-binding model, and the hopping strength, see Ref. [[209](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib209)]. The emergence of Majorana modes is shown in the bottom panel of Fig. [13](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F13 "Figure 13 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a), where the energy spectrum of a finite size one-dimensional hybrid system is presented and the Majorana modes appear at zero energy and localized at the system ends. Ref. [[164](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib164)] also showed that -wave magnetism can be utilized for realizing topological superconductivity, which, together with Ref. [[209](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib209)], clearly demonstrate the tremendous potential of unconventional magnets for realizing Majorana modes. More recently, -wave magnets have been shown to be a crucial ingredient for the emergence of Majorana flat bands when combining them in a hybrid system together with a conventional superconductor [[213](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib213)]. The authors showed that a zero-bias conductance peak signals the anomalous proximity effect [[410](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib410), [411](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib411), [412](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib412), [347](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib347), [349](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib349), [413](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib413), [414](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib414)] and can be an indicator of Majorana flat band physics [[213](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib213)], paving the route for another front to explore topological superconductivity. Interestingly, more recently, -wave magnetism was shown to be useful for realizing Majorana modes [[164](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib164)]. It is worth noting that the field requires further investigations to uncover the overall potential of unconventional magnetism for designing Majorana modes without net magnetization, which could involve addressing higher angular momentum unconventional magnets.

#### III.4.2 Superconducting diode effect

The superconducting diode effect (SDE) has recently attracted great fundamental and application-oriented interests, largely due to its experimental demonstration in several materials [[249](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib249), [415](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib415), [416](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib416), [417](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib417), [418](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib418)]; see also Ref. [[259](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib259)]. Broadly speaking, the diode effect is based on the conduction of current primarily along one direction and shown to be key building blocks for several electronic components [[419](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib419), [420](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib420), [421](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib421), [422](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib422), [423](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib423), [424](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib424)]. The SDE, on the other hand, is based on the supercurrents of superconductors which become different in opposite directions, see top panel of Fig. [13](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F13 "Figure 13 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(b). Thus, superconducting diodes exhibit functionalities that are superior than those of diodes in the normal state which suffer from energy losses due to unavoidable finite resistance [[425](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib425), [426](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib426)]. The SDE can therefore enable energy-saving applications using superconducting circuits in the future [[259](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib259)]. It is by now known that both the time-reversal and the inversion symmetry breaking are necessary conditions for the realization of the SDE although not sufficient [[422](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib422), [259](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib259), [427](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib427), [253](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib253), [252](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib252), [428](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib428)], an idea that has already led to the prediction of the SDE in bulk superconductors [[249](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib249), [252](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib252), [415](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib415), [429](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib429), [253](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib253), [430](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib430), [431](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib431), [432](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib432)]. For a time-reversal symmetric system, the opposite-going currents have the relation , where the index and are connected by time-reversal operation. If the system has inversion symmetry, is expected. Thus, it is necessary to break both time- and inversion-symmetry to generate superconducting diode effect; however, it is not sufficient to obtain the superconducting diode effect by breaking these two symmetries. Together with breaking time-reversal and inversion symmetries, Ref. [[253](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib253)] showed that breaking -inverting symmetries are also needed to realize the superconducting diode effect. The symmetry constraints for the SDE have shown to also result in the emergence of finite momentum Cooper pairs, like those in Fulde-Ferrell-Larkin-Ovchinnikov states, as well as different depairing effects between supercurrents with opposite directions [[252](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib252), [251](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib251)]. Most of the recent activity on the SDE with relatively high quality factors has involved systems with Rashba SOC, conventional superconductivity, and applied magnetic fields [[252](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib252), [253](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib253), [429](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib429), [259](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib259)]. While these are indeed relevant, the applied magnetic fields are often detrimental to superconductivity. Motivated by this fact, the SDE has very recently been explored in AMs [[145](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib145), [239](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib239), [238](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib238)], which, as discussed in Section [III](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3 "III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"), break time-reversal symmetry without an external magnetic field and exhibit zero net magnetization [[61](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib61)], conditions that are friendly with superconductivity. AMs can thus be useful for realizing field-free superconducting diodes. In Ref. ,[[238](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib238)], the authors studied the intrinsic SDE and also explored it in hybrid systems formed by AMs and superconductors, where an electric field can induce and control the SDE. In the absence of electric fields, Ref. [[238](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib238)] showed that the SDE can also appear for some non-centrosymmetric point groups. Ref. [[145](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib145)] addressed the intrinsic SDE in a -wave AM with superconductivity due to attractive interactions as in the BCS theory. Within the framework of Ginzburg-Landau theory, Ref. [[145](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib145)] finds the stabilization of pair density wave states, such as the Fulde-Ferrell and Fulde-Ferrell∗ states, which intrinsically break inversion symmetry and carry a finite momentum. In Ref. [[145](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib145)], a Fulde-Ferrell state is characterized by a single superconducting phase, while the Fulde-Ferrell∗ state by two phases. Notably, when exploring the supercurrents, the authors of Ref. [[145](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib145)] found a nonreciprocal behavior that not only distinguishes between Fulde-Ferrell and Fulde-Ferrell∗ states but also signals the emergence of the SDE in the absence of any external magnetic field. The bottom panel of Fig. [13](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F13 "Figure 13 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(b) shows the supercurrent for the Fulde-Ferrell states as a function of momentum, revealing that and are distinct and enable a field-free SDE with efficiency of [[145](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib145)]. A similar idea was a bit later addressed in Ref. [[239](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib239)] but with a -wave AM and spin-singlet pairing on nearest-neighbor bonds, which, treated within a self-consistent approach, allowed the authors to find a SDE having perfect efficiencies of under an external magnetic field. The results of the perfect SDE are ascribed to the native finite-momentum superconductivity in AMs [[239](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib239)], which the authors also show to be connected to a topological phase transition in AMs under external magnetism [[312](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib312)]. We can therefore conclude that the unique spin properties of AMs are promising for realizing superconducting diodes with a broad range of efficiencies at zero and finite magnetic fields. Nevertheless, we note that most of the theoretical works about the discussed SDE consider, in addition to altermagnetism, spin-orbit couplings which breaks the inversion symmetry. Even though the search for superconducting diodes in unconventional magnets is still in its infancy, it is very likely that other types of unconventional magnets will enrich the device functionality without relying on complicated mechanisms.

#### III.4.3 Magnetoelectric effect

The intrinsic altermagnetic properties have also been shown to be the key for inducing a magnetoelectric effect [[265](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib265), [266](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib266)], a key mechanism for superconducting spintronics [[3](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib3), [4](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib4), [5](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib5), [6](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib6), [7](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib7), [8](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib8)]. In fact, the magnetoelectric effect in superconductors occurs when an applied supercurrent generates a finite spin polarization [[433](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib433), [434](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib434), [435](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib435)], thus offering a powerful way to induce a net magnetization and a good control of spins without dissipation; see also [[436](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib436), [437](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib437), [438](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib438), [439](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib439), [440](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib440), [441](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib441)] for recent works on the magnetoelectric effect in superconductors. One of the key ingredients for the magnetoelectric effect is the breaking of inversion symmetry, e.g., due to SOC [[433](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib433), [434](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib434), [435](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib435)], where spins couple to the motion of Cooper pairs and lead to a net spin polarization tied to the applied supercurrent. These conditions are often satisfied in time-reversal invariant noncentrosymmetric superconductors [[442](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib442)], where an applied supercurrent generates a magnetization with a linear relationship between them, , where indicates the polar axis of the superconductor with Rashba SOC.

With the discovery of AMs, the exploration of the superconducting magnetoelectric effect has experienced another impetus since the altermagnetism offers unique spin-dependent properties without relying on SOC and at zero net magnetization. This allowed the study of the superconducting magnetoelectric effect in systems formed by centrosymmetric superconductors and AMs [[265](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib265), [266](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib266)]; these studies predict a nonlinear superconducting magnetoelectric effect where an out of plane magnetization induced due to an applied supercurrent in an AM-superconductor hybrid system, see top panel of Fig. [13](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F13 "Figure 13 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(c). To be more precise, Ref. [[266](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib266)] found that the emergent net magnetization is a second-order nonlinear effect given by , where is the supercurrent direction, the magnetization direction, and the Cooper pair momentum due to the applied supercurrent . Moreover, the coefficient is the second-order spin susceptibility and is nonzero only when time-reversal symmetry is broken due to altermagnetism [[266](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib266)]. To visualize the nonlinear behavior of the magnetization, the bottom panel of Fig. [13](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F13 "Figure 13 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(c) shows the results of Ref. [[266](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib266)] for an applied supercurrent along as a function of momentum. The authors of Ref. [[266](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib266)] also argue that such a second-order nonlinear superconducting magnetoelectric effect can be the dominant contribution in the out-of-plane magnetization due to the large spin splitting of AMs. Thus, unlike noncentrosymmetric superconductors with SOC, AMs allow for a nonlinear magnetoelectric effect in centrosymmetric superconductors that can be useful for a nondissipative control of magnetization. We expect that the predictions of Refs. [[265](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib265), [266](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib266)] will motivate further studies to fully exploit the distinct parities of unconventional magnets towards an efficient approach for superconducting spintronics.

#### III.4.4 Thermoelectric effect

Another line of research that has recently benefited from the interplay between altermagnetism and superconductivity is thermoelectricity, explored by combining a hybrid system formed by -wave AMs and a conventional superconductor in Ref.  [[327](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib327)], see top panel of Fig. [13](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F13 "Figure 13 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(d). Under generic circumstances, thermoelectricity is based on the direct conversion of temperature gradients into electrical quantities, a phenomenon known as the thermoelectric effect [[443](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib443), [444](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib444), [445](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib445), [446](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib446)]; see also Refs.  [[447](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib447), [448](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib448), [449](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib449), [450](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib450), [451](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib451), [452](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib452), [357](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib357), [453](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib453), [365](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib365), [454](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib454), [455](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib455), [456](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib456)]. One of the key requirements for inducing a thermoelectric effect is the breakdown of particle-hole symmetry, which, although intrinsic in superconductors, can be broken by magnetic fields. A large body of works considered hybrids systems between superconductors and ferromagnets, which managed to produce high efficiencies with figures of merit reaching even in hybrid systems based on two spin-split superconductors [[457](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib457)], see also Ref. [[458](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib458)]. These findings put ferromagnet-superconductor hybrid systems as promising for energy harvesting and cooling of electronics at cryogenic temperatures. Despite the notable properties, ferromagnets introduce undesirable stray magnetic fields that are detrimental when combining multiple structures [[459](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib459), [460](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib460), [461](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib461), [462](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib462), [463](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib463), [464](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib464), [465](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib465)], thus limiting the scalability of thermoelectric devices based on superconductors. The drawbacks of ferromagnets clearly point towards the need of finding other materials without stray fields for the thermoelectric effect in superconductors.

Ref. [[327](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib327)] showed that the above issue can be resolved in superconducting junctions with -wave AMs, as schematically shown in Fig. [13](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F13 "Figure 13 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(d). Unlike ferromagnets, AMs exhibit a momentum dependent spin splitting of energy bands without any net magnetization, which was shown to be useful for stray-field-free devices with high storage densities. The momentum dependent spin splitting of AMs enables the breaking of particle-hole symmetry for each spin, while coupling to another AM renders the interface spin active, mechanisms that permit to realize a thermoelectric response without any magnetic field. One of the main findings of Ref. [[327](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib327)] is that the AM-superconductor hybrid junction can reach a figure of merit with reasonable efficiencies, as seen in the bottom panel of Fig. [13](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.F13 "Figure 13 ‣ III.3.3 Proximity effect and inverse proximity effect ‣ III.3 Superconducting junctions formed by unconventional magnets and superconductors ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(d). The authors further showed that the behavior of the figure of merit, as well as the Seebeck coefficient, is similar to that a ferromagnet-superconductor system when temperature is varied [[327](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib327)]. This study thus opens new possibilities for exploring thermoelectricity in superconductors with unconventional magnetism, which could even further offer new ways for caloritronics in superconductors [[466](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib466), [457](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib457), [457](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib457), [467](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib467), [468](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib468)].

## IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets

In the previous section, we have delved into the understanding of the interplay between superconductivity with unconventional magnetism and also discussed the emergent phenomena when unconventional magnets are placed in contact with a superconductor. In this part, we focus on superconducting junctions formed by two superconductors linked by an unconventional magnet, also known as Josephson junctions (JJs). In these junctions, Andreev reflections at both superconducting interfaces lead to the formation of Andreev bound states (ABSs) when there is a finite phase difference between the pair potentials of the superconductors [[184](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib184), [376](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib376)]. The phase-dependent ABSs due to Andreev processes are responsible for the transfer of Cooper pairs between superconductors without any applied voltage [[469](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib469), [470](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib470), [471](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib471), [472](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib472), [473](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib473), [188](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib188), [179](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib179), [191](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib191), [474](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib474), [190](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib190), [192](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib192), [475](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib475), [182](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib182), [193](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib193)], which signals the flow of a dissipationless supercurrent also known as the Josephson effect [[476](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib476)]. Due to the superconducting nature, the ABSs and Josephson effect have been shown to be extremely useful for identifying the type of emergent superconductivity [[180](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib180), [194](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib194), [195](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib195), [181](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib181), [184](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib184), [186](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib186), [477](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib477)] and also relevant for designing superconducting devices [[478](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib478), [479](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib479), [19](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib19), [480](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib480), [20](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib20), [21](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib21), [23](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib23), [481](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib481), [482](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib482)]. In this section, we address the emergence of ABSs in JJs formed by superconductors and unconventional magnets and how the distinct types of magnetic order produce measurable signatures in the phase-biased Josephson effect.

### IV.2 Formation of Andreev bound states and their spectral signatures

To understand the impact of unconventional magnetism on the ABSs, we first remind their formation in JJs formed by semi-infinite conventional spin-singlet -wave superconductors and a normal metal [[469](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib469)], see Fig. [14](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4.F14 "Figure 14 ‣ IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a). For a short normal metal, there is a pair of spin-degenerate ABSs that emerge within the pair potential and given by , see Ref. [[469](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib469)]; here, is the superconducting phase difference and the normal transparency. The first feature to stress that the ABSs are -periodic, with and . Moreover, in the full transparent regime , the ABSs are , implying that the subgap spectrum is gapless at since the ABSs reach zero energy. In the tunneling regime , the ABSs are independent of the phase and are located near the gap edges . For a nonzero normal transmission below full transparencies, the subgap spectrum is always gapped; for instance, at , the ABSs are given by , hence the subgap spectrum exhibits an energy gap. When the normal metal becomes longer, more energy levels appear at subgap energies and the cosine-like dispersion with the phase changes to a linear dispersion in the long junction regime [[469](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib469), [196](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib196), [330](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib330)].

The features discussed in the previous paragraph are well-known and will help understand how the behaviour of the ABSs is affected when considering unconventional magnets instead of a normal metal connecting semi-infinite spin-singlet -wave superconductors in a JJ, a question addressed in Ref. [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)]. The ABSs of a short JJ as a function of the superconducting phase difference are shown in Fig. [15](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4.F15 "Figure 15 ‣ IV.1.2 Tight-binding model ‣ IV.1 Modelling Josephson junctions ‣ IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a-d) at fixed transverse momentum , obtained from the poles of in Eq. ([47](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4.E47 "In IV.1.2 Tight-binding model ‣ IV.1 Modelling Josephson junctions ‣ IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")). The first property to highlight is that, under general conditions, the JJ hosts four ABSs that are spin split and strongly dependent on the transverse momentum but with a distinct phase dependence depending on the type of unconventional magnet. For a JJ with a -wave AM, the ABSs are spin split only when , with avoided crossings (gap) around zero energy between positive and negative ABSs of the same spin, very likely due to a normal transmission effect across the unconventional magnet, see Fig. [15](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4.F15 "Figure 15 ‣ IV.1.2 Tight-binding model ‣ IV.1 Modelling Josephson junctions ‣ IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a). The authors of Ref. [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)] also showed that the ABSs profile changes when takes other values, where the energy gaps due to the avoided crossings reduce and even reach zero energy at distinct , including ; this signals a phase shift of the ABSs due to -wave altermagnetism. For JJs with a -wave AM, the ABSs also exhibit a spin splitting as in the -wave AM but their phase-dependence is slightly different, see Fig. [15](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4.F15 "Figure 15 ‣ IV.1.2 Tight-binding model ‣ IV.1 Modelling Josephson junctions ‣ IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(b). For instance, even at , the ABSs are split in spin since there already is a finite strength of the -wave field at this transverse momentum, see Eqs. ([8](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S2.E8 "In II.1 Minimal models for understanding unconventional magnetism ‣ II Unconventional magnetism in the normal state ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")) and Ref. [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)]. In this case, ABSs with distinct spins develop zero-energy crossings at distinct values of , an effect that depends on and also occurs at , unveiling also a phase shift due to -wave altermagnetism in JJs. It is interesting to note that the gapless ABSs in -wave AM based JJs are protected by a combined mirror and time-reversal symmetry. This is because the JJ Hamiltonian can be decomposed into two by exploiting the combination of mirror and time-reversal symmetries. Because the coupling between two decomposed Hamiltonian is absent, the Andreev bound states do not develop any energy gap at zero energy and they are hence gapless in Fig. [15](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4.F15 "Figure 15 ‣ IV.1.2 Tight-binding model ‣ IV.1 Modelling Josephson junctions ‣ IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets") (b). These features of the ABSs were also reported in Refs. [[198](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib198), [202](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib202)]. Thus, ABSs in JJs with -wave AMs exhibit a distinct phase dependence with respect to JJs with superconductors linked by a normal metal.

When it comes to JJs with -wave magnets, the ABSs behave slightly similar to the ABSs in JJs with a normal metal but also exhibit some differences, see Fig. [15](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4.F15 "Figure 15 ‣ IV.1.2 Tight-binding model ‣ IV.1 Modelling Josephson junctions ‣ IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(c,d). In both types of -wave magnets the ABSs develop a cosine-like profile with a finite energy gap at , with , but the spin splitting is distinct; only the ABSs in JJs with a -wave unconventional magnet seem to form a visible spin splitting since here enters as a magnetic field, see Fig. [15](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4.F15 "Figure 15 ‣ IV.1.2 Tight-binding model ‣ IV.1 Modelling Josephson junctions ‣ IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(c,d). Ref. [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)] shows that other values than the chosen in Fig. [15](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4.F15 "Figure 15 ‣ IV.1.2 Tight-binding model ‣ IV.1 Modelling Josephson junctions ‣ IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(d) give a larger spin splitting. With this, we can say that the ABSs in JJs formed by conventional superconductors and -wave magnets are different from what we discussed for JJs with AMs. At the same time, the ABSs in JJs with AMs and -wave magnets exhibit features that are distinct from JJs with normal metals, hence uncovering the impact of unconventional magnetism on the formation of ABSs.

The discussed spectral features in AMs and -wave magnets correspond to a fixed exchange field; when such a field increases, Ref. [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)] found that the subgap spectrum oscillates for JJs with AMs, with the periodicity determined by the exchange field of the respective AM. In JJs with -wave magnets, increasing the exchange field remains roughly constant the LDOS, with rather small variations in the case of -wave magnet at large exchange fields. We thus close this part by stressing that the formation of ABSs in JJs with unconventional magnets strongly depends on the type of unconventional magnetism and on the transverse direction, signatures that can be with caution identified via LDOS. It remains an open problem the behavior of ABSs in JJs with unconventional magnets having higher angular momentum dependence which will definitely shed more light on the importance of the interplay between superconductivity and unconventional magnetism.

### IV.4 Emergent phenomena due the interplay between unconventional magnetism and the Josephson effect

Apart from the already discussed unusual current-phase characteristics, the combination of unconventional magnetism and the Josephson effect also leads to novel superconducting correlations and can be used to engineer nonreciprocal Josephson transport. In particular, we stress the prediction of odd-frequency spin-triplet pairing [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)] and the realization of the Josephson diode effect [[240](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib240)], emergent phenomena that hold fundamental relevance for understanding superconductivity in JJs with unconventional magnets and also applied importance for superconducting electronics. In the following, we discuss these two discoveries.

#### IV.4.1 Odd-frequency spin-triplet pairing

As discussed in Subsection [III.2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.SS2 "III.2 Possible superconducting pair correlations due to unconventional magnetism ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"), the interplay between superconductivity and unconventional magnetism leads to novel superconducting correlations. Motivated by these results, Ref. [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)] predicted the formation of several superconducting pair symmetries by exploiting the Josephson effect and unconventional magnetism. The superconducting correlations were obtained from the anomalous electron-hole component of the Nambu Masubara Green’s functions as discussed in Section [III.2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.SS2 "III.2 Possible superconducting pair correlations due to unconventional magnetism ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets") for a JJ formed along by semi-infinite spin-singlet -wave superconductors linked by unconventional magnets; periodic boundary conditions along the transverse direction is taken, such that is a good quantum number. Among unconventional magnets, Ref. [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)] considered -wave AMs and -wave magnets, which, when coupled to the superconductors, were shown to host superconducting correlations having symmetries similar but also distinct to that of the parent superconductor. Notably, for -wave magnets and -wave AMs, Ref. [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)] finds spin-triplet superconducting correlations belong to the ETO and OTE symmetry classes discussed in Subsection [III.2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.SS2 "III.2 Possible superconducting pair correlations due to unconventional magnetism ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"), respectively, whose parity symmetry is determined by the symmetry of unconventional magnetism. For instance, for JJs with -wave AMs, the OTE pair amplitude has an even parity that is determined by the combination of the odd dependence under the exchange of spatial coordinates and odd in ; the oddness in entirely arises due to the magnetic order, given that the altermagnetic field of a -wave AM is odd under . Similarly, the parity symmetry of the OTE pairing in JJs with -wave AMs is determined by the evenness in space and in momentum along the transverse direction. The role of AMs for affecting the parity of emergent superconducting correlations was already discussed in Subsection [III.2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.SS2 "III.2 Possible superconducting pair correlations due to unconventional magnetism ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"). However, the most relevant finding of Ref. [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)] is that the formation of OTE pairing can be controlled by the interplay between altermagnetism and the Josephson effect. To visualize this fact, we show in Fig. [18](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4.F18 "Figure 18 ‣ IV.4 Emergent phenomena due the interplay between unconventional magnetism and the Josephson effect ‣ IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(a,b) the square absolute value of the OTE pairing in the middle of a -wave AM integrated over as a function of the altermagnetic field and the superconducting phase difference , see also Ref. [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160)]. As observed, a finite OTE pairing is induced only when both the altermagnetic field and , which not only unveils the formation of novel superconducting correlations but also suggest that they are important in the proximity effect of JJs formed by AMs. An interesting open problem is perhaps to explore how long in space survive these pair correlations, which could take us further to understand and realize a long-range proximity effect in JJs with AMs and their extension to -wave magnets as well. Studies of this kind are necessary for envisaging Josephson devices hosting spin-polarized supercurrents [[3](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib3)] useful for superconducting spintronics [[3](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib3), [4](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib4), [5](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib5), [6](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib6), [7](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib7), [8](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib8)], which can be achieved using unconventional magnets at zero net magnetization.

#### IV.4.2 The Josephson diode effect

In the Josephson diode effect, nonreciprocity occurs in the supercurrents driven by the Josephson effect [[498](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib498), [250](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib250), [251](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib251), [499](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib499), [246](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib246), [247](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib247), [500](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib500), [258](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib258), [257](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib257), [501](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib501), [244](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib244), [260](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib260), [248](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib248)], which by now has already motivated an intense experimental activity [[502](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib502), [503](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib503), [254](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib254), [255](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib255), [504](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib504), [415](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib415), [259](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib259), [505](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib505), [506](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib506)]. More specifically, in a similar way as for the superconducting diode effect in bulk superconductors, the Josephson diode effect involves the nonreciprocity of maximum and minimum critical currents , where . Thus, the Josephson diode efficiency is quantified by quality factor given by Eq. ([40](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.E40 "In III.4.2 Superconducting diode effect ‣ III.4 Emergent superconducting phenomena in unconventional magnets ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")) but involving the maximum and minimum Josephson currents. We can also see that the antisymmetric dependence of the supercurrent with the phase is broken, namely, ; hence, the Josephson diode effect requires current-phase curves that are distinct to what is obtained in conventional JJs. As for the superconducting diode discussed in Subsection [III.4.2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.SS4.SSS2 "III.4.2 Superconducting diode effect ‣ III.4 Emergent superconducting phenomena in unconventional magnets ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"), the Josephson diode effect also requires breaking time-reversal and inversion symmetries as necessary but not sufficient conditions. Ref. [[253](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib253)] showed that, breaking time-reversal and inversion symmetries, needs to be combined with breaking -inverting symmetries in order to induce nonreciprocal Josephson transport. These conditions can be easily achieved in JJs formed by semiconductors which exhibit intrinsic SOC under the presence of external magnetic fields breaking time-reversal and -inverting symmetries. In terms of supercurrent harmonics, when the Josephson current is decomposed as , the discussed symmetry Josephson diode requirements were shown in Ref. [[246](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib246)] to be directly connected to the Josephson current exhibiting the simultaneous coexistence of the harmonics , , and [[246](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib246)]. Thus, a Josephson diode effect is possible when , and coexist, maximizing the efficiency when such harmonics are comparable in magnitude [[253](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib253)].

Given the requirements for Josephson diodes, JJs formed by AMs represent an interesting and promising ground. This is because AMs exhibit broken time-reversal symmetry and have a momentum dependent magnetic field akin to SOC but of not relativistic origin, already shown to be important for superconducting diodes in bulk superconductors and whose extension to JJs is hence natural, see Subsection [III.4.2](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S3.SS4.SSS2 "III.4.2 Superconducting diode effect ‣ III.4 Emergent superconducting phenomena in unconventional magnets ‣ III Superconductivity and unconventional magnetism ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"). Exploring AMs for Josephson diodes is further supported by the findings of Refs. [[160](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib160), [172](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib172)] discussed in Subsection [IV.3](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4.SS3 "IV.3 The Josephson effect and current-phase characteristics ‣ IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets"), where the current-phase characteristics of JJs with AMs were shown to exhibit multiple harmonics (), thus being promising for the Josephson diode effect according to Ref. [[246](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib246)] if an additional mechanism is able to allow for . In this regard, can be induced e. g., by an external magnetic field or perhaps other spin-dependent fields, which then implies that and the Josephson diode effect can be realized. So far, there exist limited studies reporting the Josephson diode effect in a JJ formed by conventional spin-singlet -wave superconductors with -wave altermagnetism and also Rashba SOC [[240](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib240), [241](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib241)]; see Refs. [[242](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib242), [243](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib243)] for AM-based Josephson diodes using unconventional superconductors. In the top panel of Fig. [18](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4.F18 "Figure 18 ‣ IV.4 Emergent phenomena due the interplay between unconventional magnetism and the Josephson effect ‣ IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(b), the current-phase curves of Ref. [[240](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib240)] are shown for distinct values of the orientation angle that controls the -wave altermagnetism and the Rashba SOC. The distinct values of maximum and minimum values of and the finite quality factors in the bottom panel of Fig. [18](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#S4.F18 "Figure 18 ‣ IV.4 Emergent phenomena due the interplay between unconventional magnetism and the Josephson effect ‣ IV Josephson junctions with unconventional magnets ‣ Superconducting phenomena in systems with unconventional magnets")(b) clearly show the emergence of the Josephson diode effect using -wave AMs. While these findings are indeed encouraging, Ref. [[240](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib240)] showed that the Josephson diode needs the simultaneous presence of altermagnetism and Rashba SOC, vanishing if SOC is zero. More recently, it has been predicted the possibility to realize a field-free Josephson diode effect by combining AMs and Ising superconductor in a JJ [[243](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib243)], while Ref. [[242](https://arxiv.org/html/2502.15400v3#bib.bib242)] combined AMs with spin-singlet and spin-triplet superconductors in a JJ. This then makes us wonder if it is possible at all to realize Josephson diodes by simply using AMs or they always need to be combined with other materials. One way could be to combine them with -wave magnets or other higher angular momentum unconventional magnets since, under certain circumstances, they also offer a spin splitting of energy bands. Pursuing these ideas have an immediate impact in superconducting electronics where Josephson diodes can be utilized.
