## III Methodology

### III.1 Preprocessing and Data Cleaning

A clean database is essential to analysis with any machine learning algorithm [[42](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib42)]. The notion of “Garbage in, garbage out” holds true, if a model is trained on flawed data, its predictions are bound to be unreliable. In materials science research, data availability is often a significant challenge, constrained by small databases.

Here, we use the SuperCon database maintained by NIMS, Japan [[43](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib43)], which was initiated following the discovery of high- superconductors. Three versions of this database are currently available, primarily containing information on the chemical formula, , the reporting journal, structural details, and measurement methods such as onset, the temperature at which the superconducting transition begins, at zero resistance, the temperature at which zero resistance is achieved, and magnetization studies for some compounds. The SuperCon database cleaned and published by Stanev et al. [[22](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib22)] in 2018 includes 16,414 compounds. A later version, SuperCon - Ver.220808 [[44](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib44)], contains 33,406 compounds, while the most recent release, SuperCon - Ver.240322 [[45](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib45)], includes 26,358 compounds. Both the 2018 [[22](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib22)] and 2024 [[45](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib45)] databases, have no missing ’s. Unlike, SuperCon - Ver.220808[[44](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib44)], which contains missing entries for .

The data-cleaning algorithm consists of four steps: pre-processing, repetition cleaning, database comparison and manual addition of compounds to the database. Fig. [1](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#S3.F1 "Figure 1 ‣ III.1 Preprocessing and Data Cleaning ‣ III Methodology ‣ Accelerating the Search for Superconductors Using Machine Learning") shows graphical representation of our data cleaning workflow.

1. 1.

   Pre-processing : This step ensures that all compounds in the database follow the required format of chemical formula to facilitate feature generation. Since our model relies solely on composition-based features, we focus on cleaning the database to ensure the validity of chemical compositions.

   * •

     If an element appears more than once in a chemical formula, we consolidate its composition at the first occurrence of that element. E.g.,
   * •

     Compounds with incorrect chemical formulas were identified manually. Their formulas were corrected by referring to the cited journal. E.g., and .
   * •

     We remove compounds with variable or invalid stoichiometric numbers, as well as those containing unsupported characters such as ‘+’, ‘-’, ‘!’, or ‘=’, since these cannot be practically used for feature generation. E.g., , , .
   * •

     Compounds with a stoichiometric number of 150 or greater were removed, as such unbalanced systems are rarely found. E.g.,

   This process is applied consistently to all the entries in the databases.
2. 2.

   Repetition Cleaning: Since our feature generation process involves normalization of the composition, different representations of the same compound become indistinguishable. For example and are indistinguishable. We identify such entries in the database and average out their critical temperature values. For SuperCon-Stanev database we simply take the averaged critical temperature. For SuperCon - Ver.220808 and SuperCon - Ver.240322 we retain the compound with averaged only if their standard deviation is less than 5 K . In the SuperCon-Stanev database, we do not apply this standard deviation filter, as critical temperatures in this database will later be updated using the most recent data from SuperCon - Ver.240322.
3. 3.

   Database Comparison: Comparison of the cleaned versions of SuperCon - Ver.220808 and SuperCon - Ver.240322, shows that all 12,950 compounds in SuperCon - Ver.220808 are present in SuperCon - Ver.240322. Similarly, on comparing SuperCon-Stanev with that of SuperCon - Ver.240322, 11,930 compounds in SuperCon-Stanev have critical temperature reported in both the database, while the remaining 3,916 compounds in SuperCon-Stanev have reported critical temperature of 0 K, but are absent in the latest database. Manual search of these compounds shows that some are superconductors, while others are not. It seems that the database of Stanev et al. [[22](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib22)] has imputed the missing data, which is not a good approach for ML model, which would learn from wrong data. Hence, we do manual search of such compounds and update their data back to the database as explained in the next step.
4. 4.

   Manual Addition: We manually checked the cited journals for the 3,916 compounds with reported critical temperature of 0 K. A compound is added back to the database only if the source explicitly confirms its superconducting nature or lack thereof.

   * •

     Many compounds exhibit superconductivity alongside magnetic ordering, charge density waves, or spin density waves. We retain a compound in the database only if it is observed to exhibit superconductivity or no superconductivity. E.g, [[46](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib46)], the phase diagram reported in the cited paper identifies it as an antiferromagnet without superconductivity, We thus update its as 0 K.
   * •

     As absolute zero is unattainable, some research articles report that a compound might be superconducting below the lowest attainable temperature of the apparatus. If such lower limit is 0.1 K or lower, we approximate its as 0 K.
   * •

     Many published works do not report numerical value of for a given composition but provide magnetization, resistivity, specific heat studies, or phase diagrams plots. We manually analyzed over 150 images and interpolated critical temperature from these graphs. In cases where multiple studies report different values for the same compound, we recorded their average. By following this criterion, we were able to add 1,337 of the 3,916 compounds back into the database.
   * •

     A machine learning model will be biased if it is trained only on superconductors. To the cleaned database which contains about 1,100 non-superconductors, we add 455 more non-superconductors, along with 43 superconductors reported by Hosono et al [[47](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib47)]. Additionally, through our review of the literature, we identified and manually added 55 materials exhibiting both superconducting and non-superconducting behavior that were not present in the original database. Upon addition of these compounds, some repetition arose, we average the critical temperature of such repeated compounds and retain them only if the standard deviation is less than 5 K. This final cleaned database is referred to as ‘SuperCon-MTG’ named after the ‘Materials Theory Group’. SuperCon-MTG is a cleaned and augmented version of the SuperCon database originally developed and maintained by NIMS Japan [[43](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib43), [45](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib45)]. The original dataset is available under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0) license.

### III.2 Machine Learning Workflow

Non-superconductors are considered to have a critical temperature of 0 K in our database. However, accurately predicting 0 K using regression-based machine learning algorithms is challenging. To address this, we strategize our workflow by performing a classification step followed by regression on the predicted superconductors.

Specifically, we first classify whether a material is a superconductor or a non-superconductor. If a compound is predicted to be a superconductor, we apply regression-based machine learning models to estimate its critical temperature. Otherwise, we assign it a critical temperature of 0 K. This two-step approach enhances the reliability of our machine learning predictions. Fig. [2](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#S3.F2 "Figure 2 ‣ III.1 Preprocessing and Data Cleaning ‣ III Methodology ‣ Accelerating the Search for Superconductors Using Machine Learning") provides a graphical representation of our machine learning workflow.

## IV Results

The SuperCon-MTG database hosts 13,731 compounds, including both reported superconductors and non superconducting compounds, after the data cleaning with algorithm described in Sec [III.1](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#S3.SS1 "III.1 Preprocessing and Data Cleaning ‣ III Methodology ‣ Accelerating the Search for Superconductors Using Machine Learning"). The cleaned database contains 1,584 non-superconducting compounds with a critical temperature of 0 K. The highest reported critical temperature in the dataset is 143 K for [[48](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib48)]. The average critical temperature of the compounds in the dataset is 21.2 K. The first quartile () lies below 2.05 K, meaning that 25% of compounds in the database have critical temperature 2.05 K. The second quartile () is below 7.5 K and third quartile () falls below 29.6 K.

A clear class imbalance exists between superconductors and non-superconductors, as the number of superconducting materials is significantly higher. This imbalance arises due to limited availability of labeled non-superconducting materials data in materials science. Despite the existence of well-maintained theoretical and experimental databases such as Materials Project [[34](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib34)] which hosts over 150,000 inorganic materials, The Open Quantum Materials Database (OQMD) [[49](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib49)], which contains over 1.2 million DFT calculated thermodynamic and structural properties and the Inorganic Crystal Structure Database (ICSD) [[50](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib50)] hosting more than 300,000 experimetally determined compounds, none of these databases explicitly label materials as superconducting / non-superconducting. Due to this limitation, we cannot manually add materials from these datasets to balance the classes, which makes it difficult to ensure a well-distributed dataset for machine learning models.

We classify the compounds in SuperCon-MTG into twenty-four classes based on their chemical composition. Cuprates (copper oxide compounds) constitute the largest fraction, accounting for 34.3% of the database, followed by alloys at 20%. Iron chalcogenides make up approximately 5.6%, Iron pnictides 4.8%, and Heavy Fermion compounds around 4.4%. Unidentified class of compounds fall under ‘Unclassified’ constituting 4.6%. The remaining 18 classes collectively contribute 26.3% to the database. The extensive research on cuprates, driven by their potential as high superconductors, is evident from their dominant presence, making up nearly one-third of the dataset.

### IV.1 Unsupervised Learning: Principal Component Analysis

Previous studies have demonstrated the clustering of compounds in the vs. space [[39](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib39), [40](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib40)]. This clustering arises because certain classes of materials exhibit superconducting critical temperatures within specific ranges and tend to share common crystal structures. As a result, clustering in this space is a natural consequence rather than an insightful distinction. In our analysis, we extend this idea by projecting superconducting materials into two principal components using Principal Component Analysis (PCA). We observe distinct clustering patterns, with compounds grouping according to their structural and chemical similarities. Notably, cuprates, elemental superconductors, and carbon-based compounds exhibit clear clustering. Other classes also cluster, though with some degree of overlap between different groups, making their boundary diffused. Clustering of these compounds in PCA space can be seen as in Fig. [4](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#S4.F4 "Figure 4 ‣ IV.1 Unsupervised Learning: Principal Component Analysis ‣ IV Results ‣ Accelerating the Search for Superconductors Using Machine Learning").

### IV.2 Hyperparameter Tuning

Random Forest [[51](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib51)] is an ensemble learning method that constructs multiple decision trees using bagging. Specifically, it selects random samples with replacement (bootstrapping) from the dataset to train each tree. This means that after a sample is drawn from the dataset, it is returned to the bag, making it possible for the same sample to be selected multiple times for training different trees. For regression tasks, the final output is the average prediction of individual trees, whereas for classification, it is determined by majority voting. This random sampling process helps reduce overfitting and variance.

The Random Forest model consistently outperforms both XGBoost [[52](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib52)] and Extra Trees for classification and regression tasks related to superconductivity prediction (see Supplementary Information Sec. II [[41](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib41)] for details). The overall workflow is outlined in Sec [III.2](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#S3.SS2 "III.2 Machine Learning Workflow ‣ III Methodology ‣ Accelerating the Search for Superconductors Using Machine Learning").

### IV.3 SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) Analysis of the Random Forest Model

Random Forest is a black-box model, making it difficult to interpret the decision-making process behind its predictions. Explainable AI (XAI) is a field in artificial intelligence that aims to make models more interpretable and explainable. Some of the most commonly used XAI techniques are SHAP [[33](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib33)] and LIME [[54](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib54)].

SHAP explains machine learning model predictions using ideas from game theory. It fairly distributes the contribution of each feature to the final predictions by calculating Shapley values [[55](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib55)], which represent each feature’s average marginal contribution across all possible coalitions. A higher Shapley (SHAP) value indicates that the feature increases the predicted value by that amount relative to the model’s baseline value, which is the average of the predicted value over the training dataset. The baseline value for our model in 23.6 K.

In Fig. [7](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#S4.F7 "Figure 7 ‣ IV.3 SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) Analysis of the Random Forest Model ‣ IV Results ‣ Accelerating the Search for Superconductors Using Machine Learning"), we present a bar plot of the mean absolute SHAP values for each feature, which indicates the ranking of feature importance. A higher mean absolute SHAP value signifies a greater impact on the model’s predictions but does not indicate whether an increase in the feature value leads to a positive or negative SHAP value. ‘Maximum orbital radius’ is the most important feature driving critical temperature prediction, followed by ‘Median electronegativity’, while the last bar represents the contribution of the remaining 21 features.

In Fig. 8, we present feature distributions displayed as violin plot illustrating the relationship between feature values and SHAP values. The feature ‘Maxima Orbital Radius’, which has the most significant influence on critical temperature, tends to decrease the critical temperature from the baseline value as the feature value increases. Conversely, ‘Median Orbital Radius’ exhibits a negative SHAP value for higher feature values and a positive SHAP value for lower feature values, meaning that lower values of this feature increase the predicted critical temperature above the baseline, while higher values decrease it below the baseline.

### IV.5 Classwise performance of Machine Learning Model

Around 12,384 compounds are classified as superconductors in SuperCon-MTG using Random Forest classification model in Sec [IV.2.1](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#S4.SS2.SSS1 "IV.2.1 Classification ‣ IV.2 Hyperparameter Tuning ‣ IV Results ‣ Accelerating the Search for Superconductors Using Machine Learning") . These materials fall into 24 distinct classes based on the chemical composition. We train a random forest regression model to predict critical temperature for each class of these compounds, to improve the reliability of ML model predictions, we merge smaller classes with fewer than 170 entries, ensuring adequate dataset size for training. More details on the statistics of classes of compounds can be found in Supplementary Information (SI), Section IV [[41](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib41)].

We combine -based materials and bismuthates into a new class called Bi-based compounds. Additionally, A15, Chevrel, Dichalcogenides, Elemental superconductors, Hydrides, Other Iron based materials and unclassified materials are grouped into a single class labeled as the Rest of the compounds.

The score and normalized error, defined as the ratio of the root mean squared error to the average critical temperature of each class, are as shown in Fig. [10](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#S4.F10 "Figure 10 ‣ IV.5 Classwise performance of Machine Learning Model ‣ IV Results ‣ Accelerating the Search for Superconductors Using Machine Learning"). We observe that the random forest model predicts the critical temperature reasonably well for Bi-based materials [[56](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib56)] and borocarbides [[57](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib57)], both of which are potentially unconventional superconductors. Similarly, it performs well for transition metal pnictides [[58](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib58)] and borides [[59](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib59)], which are considered conventional superconductors. On the other hand, the accuracy of model predictions for ’s of other classes of superconductors such as cuprates, nitrides, oxides, and iron-based pnictides and chalcogenides, are relatively lower. This indicates that the class-wise trained model performs well for classes where compositional trends dominate, while its performance slightly declines for classes where crystal structure may play a more significant role. Overall, the model shows reasonably good performance and generalizes prediction effectively, when trained across classes using only composition-based features.

## V Search for Superconducting Materials

### V.1 Superconductors from the Literature

In the previous section, we demonstrated that our machine learning model is reasonably robust in classifying materials as superconductors and predicting their . To further validate its performance beyond the SuperCon-MTG dataset, we evaluate materials reported after 2016 that are not included in the training or test datasets. We select 27 compounds that are known to exhibit superconductivity. Our model successfully classifies all of these 27 materials as superconductors and provides reasonably accurate critical temperature predictions. The results are presented in Table [4](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#S5.T4 "Table 4 ‣ V.1 Superconductors from the Literature ‣ V Search for Superconducting Materials ‣ Accelerating the Search for Superconductors Using Machine Learning"). The and columns represent predictions using machine learning models with 30 and 5 descriptors, respectively.

### V.2 Using the compounds in Materials Project

To identify potential superconducting materials, we screen compounds from the Materials Project database [[34](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib34)], which hosts over 150,000 inorganic materials. We refine our selection by filtering for nonmagnetic, metallic, and experimentally reported compounds that are also present in the ICSD [[50](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib50)] and Pauling File database [[73](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib73)], as illustrated in Fig. [11](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#S5.F11 "Figure 11 ‣ V.2 Using the compounds in Materials Project ‣ V Search for Superconducting Materials ‣ Accelerating the Search for Superconductors Using Machine Learning"). This reduces the dataset to approximately 15,352 compounds, of which around 1,606 are already listed in SuperCon-MTG, leaving approximately 13,746 candidate materials. We apply our machine learning model to this refined dataset to identify potential superconducting materials. The top 10 compounds with the highest predicted critical temperatures, as determined using both the 30-feature and 5-feature models, are presented in Table [5](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#S5.T5 "Table 5 ‣ V.2 Using the compounds in Materials Project ‣ V Search for Superconducting Materials ‣ Accelerating the Search for Superconductors Using Machine Learning"). 4 of these 10 compounds turn out to be reported superconductors, but not present in SuperCon-MTG. The predicted critical temperatures for , , and from both the 30-feature and 5-feature models are very close to the corresponding experimental values. For , the prediction from the 30-feature model aligns well with the experimental , while the 5-feature model underestimates it, though it still successfully identifies the compound as a superconductor. The remaining six materials are new predictions and should be tested for superconductivity. Most of the compounds listed in Table [5](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#S5.T5 "Table 5 ‣ V.2 Using the compounds in Materials Project ‣ V Search for Superconducting Materials ‣ Accelerating the Search for Superconductors Using Machine Learning") contain copper in the +2 oxidation state. In , copper exists in both +1 and +2 oxidation states. In , the average oxidation state of copper is +2.25, with three copper atoms in the +2 state and one in the +3 state. The presence of copper in the +2 state suggests that hole doping is required for the material to exhibit superconductivity.

One limitation of our model is that it is mostly trained on materials which are metallic or possess a small band gap. So, our predictions are expected to be most reliable for compounds with metallic or narrow-gap materials.

### V.3 Unexplored Space of materials

Manual search for potential superconducting materials within the Materials Project database is rather a time intensive and impractical process. To streamline this process, we use the SMACT library [[78](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib78)] in Python to generate binary compositions consisting of one transition metal and one main group element (details provided in Supplementary Information, Sec. V [[41](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib41)]). Elements from the 7th period, noble gases, and radioactive elements such as Tc, Po, and At are excluded. The generated compositions are then validated based on fundamental chemical principles, ensuring charge neutrality and conditions on electronegativity.

Furthermore, we compute the probability of these generated compounds to exist using the given oxidation states of constituents (see Supplementary Information Sec VI [[41](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#bib.bib41)]) and retain only those with a probability greater than zero. This filtering process reduces the initial 5,085 possible compositions to 292, of which 19 are already listed in SuperCon-MTG. We further refine the dataset of remaining 273 compounds by applying the filtering criteria outlined in Fig. [11](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#S5.F11 "Figure 11 ‣ V.2 Using the compounds in Materials Project ‣ V Search for Superconducting Materials ‣ Accelerating the Search for Superconductors Using Machine Learning"). From this, we shortlist 11 materials, 4 of which have already been reported as superconductors, predominantly in studies published after 2016, as presented in Table [6](https://arxiv.org/html/2505.11964v1#S5.T6 "Table 6 ‣ V.3 Unexplored Space of materials ‣ V Search for Superconducting Materials ‣ Accelerating the Search for Superconductors Using Machine Learning"). ## VI Summary

In this work, we present a workflow to modify and refine existing dataset of superconducting compounds and present a cleaner and curated version. Using ideas from Quantum Structure Diagrams, we demonstrate clustering of superconducting compounds by their classes in principal component plane revealing meaningful structure in the data. Building on this foundation, we developed a machine learning framework for efficient classification of materials as superconductor, and predict its directly from its chemical composition. Remarkably, the model requires neither crystallographic information nor physical theory-based features, relying solely on Quantum Structure Diagram based descriptors and Random forest classification and regression algorithms. Importantly, the model generalizes well beyond the SuperCon-MTG dataset, accurately predicting superconductivity in newly discovered compounds for superconductivity. We also identify several promising candidates for superconductivity, which will stimulate experiments to validate. This showcases our model’s potential to accelerate the discovery of novel superconducting materials.

[1] [arXiv:2509.20480](/abs/2509.20480 "Abstract") [[pdf](/pdf/2509.20480 "Download PDF"), [html](https://arxiv.org/html/2509.20480v1 "View HTML"), [other](/format/2509.20480 "Other formats")]
:   Title: Revisiting dissipation-driven phase transition in a Josephson junction

    [Diego Subero](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Subero,+D), [Yu-Cheng-Chang](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Yu-Cheng-Chang), [Miguel Monteiro](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Monteiro,+M), [Ze-Yan Chen](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Chen,+Z), [Jukka P. Pekola](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Pekola,+J+P)

    Comments: 6 pages, 4 figures

    Subjects: Superconductivity (cond-mat.supr-con); Mesoscale and Nanoscale Physics (cond-mat.mes-hall)

    Despite extensive experimental and theoretical work over several decades, Schmid-Bulgadaev quantum phase transition remains a subject of debate. Here we revisit this problem by performing systematic experiments on low-frequency current-voltage characteristics of Josephson junctions over a wide range of parameters. The experiments are conducted in a true resistive environment formed by a metallic on-chip resistor located near the junction. Over the parameter range of the experiment, we find that the transition occurs when the resistance crosses the quantum value $h/(4e^2)\simeq 6.5$ k$\Omega$ for Cooper pairs, as originally predicted. The temperature $T$ of the experiment is naturally non-zero, but our basic theoretical modeling corroborates that the observations under these conditions can serve as the basis for the conclusions made, in particular, the crossover resistance from superconducting to insulating regime is the same as that at $T=0$.

[2] [arXiv:2509.20650](/abs/2509.20650 "Abstract") [[pdf](/pdf/2509.20650 "Download PDF"), [other](/format/2509.20650 "Other formats")]
:   Title: Effect of C additives with 0.5% in weight on structural, optical and superconducting properties of Ta-Nb-Hf-Zr-Ti high entropy alloy films

    [Tien Le](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Le,+T), [Yeonkyu Lee](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Lee,+Y), [Dzung T. Tran](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Tran,+D+T), [Woo Seok Choi](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Choi,+W+S), [Won Nam Kang](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Kang,+W+N), [Jinyoung Yun](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Yun,+J), [Jeehoon Kim](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Kim,+J), [Jaegu Song](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Song,+J), [Yoonseok Han](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Han,+Y), [Tuson Park](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Park,+T), [Duc H. Tran](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Tran,+D+H), [Soon-Gil Jung](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Jung,+S), [Jungseek Hwang](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Hwang,+J)

    Comments: 27 pages, 7 figures

    Journal-ref: Journal of Alloys and Compounds 1008, 176863/1-8 (2024)

    Subjects: Superconductivity (cond-mat.supr-con); Materials Science (cond-mat.mtrl-sci)

    We investigated the superconducting (SC) properties of Ta-Nb-Hf-Zr-Ti high-entropy alloy (HEA) thin films with 0.5% weight C additives. The C additives stabilize the structural properties and enhance the SC critical properties, including $\mu\_0$Hc$\_2$ (13.45 T) and Tc (7.5 K). The reflectance of the C-added HEA film is enhanced in the low-energy region, resulting in a higher optical conductivity, which is consistent with the lower electrical resistivity. In addition, we observed SC vortices in the C-added HEA film using magnetic force microscopy. The magnetic penetration depths ($\lambda$) of the pure HEA and C-added HEA films were estimated from their Meissner force curves by comparing them with those of a reference Nb film. At 4.2 K, the {\lambda} of the C-added film is 360 nm, shorter than that of the pure HEA film (560 nm), indicating stronger superconductivity against an applied magnetic field.

[3] [arXiv:2509.20727](/abs/2509.20727 "Abstract") [[pdf](/pdf/2509.20727 "Download PDF"), [html](https://arxiv.org/html/2509.20727v1 "View HTML"), [other](/format/2509.20727 "Other formats")]
:   Title: Distinct orbital contributions to electronic and magnetic structures in La$\_{4}$Ni$\_{3}$O$\_{10}$

    [Shilong Zhang](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Zhang,+S), [Hengyuang Zhang](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Zhang,+H), [Zehao Dong](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Dong,+Z), [Jie Li](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Li,+J), [Qian Xiao](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Xiao,+Q), [Mengwu Huo](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Huo,+M), [Hsiao-Yu Huang](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Huang,+H), [Di-Jing Huang](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Huang,+D), [Yayu Wang](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Wang,+Y), [Yi Lu](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Lu,+Y), [Zhen Chen](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Chen,+Z), [Meng Wang](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Wang,+M), [Yingying Peng](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Peng,+Y)

    Subjects: Superconductivity (cond-mat.supr-con); Strongly Correlated Electrons (cond-mat.str-el)

    High-T$\_c$ superconductivity has recently been discovered in Ruddlesden-Popper phase nickelates under pressure, where the low-energy electronic structure is dominated by Ni $d\_{x^2 - y^2}$ and $d\_{z^2}$ orbitals. However, the respective roles of these orbitals in superconductivity remain unclear. Here, by combining X-ray absorption, electron energy loss spectroscopy, and density functional theory calculations on La$\_{4}$Ni$\_{3}$O$\_{10}$ single crystals, we identify ligand holes in the $p\_{x,y}$ orbitals of planar oxygen and the $p\_z$ orbitals of apical oxygen, which hybridize with the Ni $d\_{x^2-y^2}$ and $d\_{z^2}$ orbitals, respectively. These ligand holes enable orbital-selective O K-edge resonant inelastic X-ray scattering (RIXS) study, which reveals that $d\_{x^2-y^2}$ states dominate the low-energy charge excitations and are more itinerant. We also observe a $\sim$0.1 eV bimagnon through RIXS and Raman spectroscopy, which leads to an interlayer superexchange interaction J$\_z$ of $\sim$50 meV. Our results reveal distinct contributions of Ni $d\_{x^2-y^2}$ and $d\_{z^2}$ orbitals to the electronic and magnetic structure and provide direct experimental insights to understand the RP-phase nickelate superconductors.

[4] [arXiv:2509.20742](/abs/2509.20742 "Abstract") [[pdf](/pdf/2509.20742 "Download PDF"), [html](https://arxiv.org/html/2509.20742v1 "View HTML"), [other](/format/2509.20742 "Other formats")]
:   Title: Ambient-pressure superconductivity above 22 K in hole-doped YB2

    [Xuejie Li](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Li,+X), [Wenbo zhao](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=zhao,+W), [Yuzhou Hao](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Hao,+Y), [Xiaoying Wang](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Wang,+X), [Zhibin Gao](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Gao,+Z), [Xiangdong Ding](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Ding,+X)

    Subjects: Superconductivity (cond-mat.supr-con)

    Recent studies of hydrogen-dominant (superhydride) materials, such as LaH10 have led to putative discoveries of near-room temperature superconductivity at high pressures, with a superconducting transition temperature (Tc) of 250 K observed at 170 GPa. While these findings are promising, achieving such high superconductivity requires challenging experimental conditions typically exceeding 100 GPa. In this study, we utilize first-principles calculations and Migdal-Eliashberg theory to examine the superconducting properties of the stable boron-based compound YB2 at atmospheric pressure, where yttrium and boron atoms form a layered structure. Our results indicate that YB2 exhibits a Tc of 2.14 K at 0 GPa. We find that doping with additional electrons (0 to 0.3) leads to a monotonic decrease in Tc as the electron concentration increases. Conversely, introducing holes significantly enhances Tc, raising it to 22.83 K. Although our findings do not surpass the superconducting temperature of the well-known MgB2, our doping strategy highlights a method for tuning electron-phonon coupling strength in metal borides. This insight could be valuable for future experi-mental applications. Overall, this study not only deepens our understanding of YB2 superconducting properties but also contributes to the ongoing search for high-temperature superconductors.

[5] [arXiv:2509.20782](/abs/2509.20782 "Abstract") [[pdf](/pdf/2509.20782 "Download PDF"), [other](/format/2509.20782 "Other formats")]
:   Title: Field-resilient superconducting coplanar waveguide resonators made of Nb, NbTi, and NbTiN

    [Bongkeon Kim](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Kim,+B), [Chang Geun Yu](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Yu,+C+G), [Priyanath Mal](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Mal,+P), [Yong-Joo Doh](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Doh,+Y)

    Comments: 18 pages, 5 figures

    Subjects: Superconductivity (cond-mat.supr-con)

    Superconducting coplanar waveguide (SCPW) resonators with high internal quality factors (\Q\_i) are essential for quantum information applications, but suffer severe Qi degradation under magnetic fields due to quasiparticle generation and vortex-induced losses. We fabricated and characterized Nb, NbTi, and NbTiN SCPW resonators with varying film thicknesses under different temperatures and in-plane magnetic fields (\(B\_{\parallel}\)). Temperature-dependent transmission measurements agree well with Mattis-Bardeen theory, revealing kinetic inductance parameters. Comparative analysis shows that 45-nm-thick NbTi resonators maintain \(Q\_i = 1.01 \times 10^{4}\) at (\(B\_{\parallel}\)) = 0.4 T, satisfying the dual requirements of high Qi and strong field resilience. Owing to its moderate kinetic inductance and compatibility with conventional photolithography, NbTi emerges as a practical material platform for field-resilient SCPW resonators and hybrid quantum circuits operating in magnetic environments.

[6] [arXiv:2509.21120](/abs/2509.21120 "Abstract") [[pdf](/pdf/2509.21120 "Download PDF"), [other](/format/2509.21120 "Other formats")]
:   Title: Room-temperature superconductivity in ultra-thin carbon nanotube zeolite composites: a conventional or unconventional superconductor?

    [Chi Ho Wong](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Wong,+C+H), [Rolf Lortz](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Lortz,+R)

    Subjects: Superconductivity (cond-mat.supr-con)

    The recent report of signs of room-temperature superconductivity in ultrathin single-walled carbon nanotubes (CNT) of types (2,1) and (3,0) holds significant promise for energy applications due to their ability to conduct current without dissipation. However, the McMillan Tc formula fails to calculate their superconducting transition temperatures (Tc) accurately, which raises an important question: what is the pairing mechanism driving their room-temperature superconductivity? To explore this further, we first investigate whether the strong curvature of ultrathin CNT leads to exotic phenomena in unconventional superconductors. If no evidence of these exotic characteristics is found and the McMillan formalism indicates that it is not a BCS-type superconductor, could we be observing a new class of unconventional superconductivity that functions independently of phonons and typical exotic features? In this paper, we demonstrate that factors such as the chiral angle of CNT, boron dopants and lattice regularity can be used to tune the theoretical Tc to experimental values. Our finding suggests that combining CNT with a harder substrate could be vital for further enhancing Tc while minimizing lattice distortion under doping. We propose a reconsideration of the common belief regarding whether the McMillan and BCS Tc formulas are adequate for classifying materials as BCS or non-BCS superconductors.

[7] [arXiv:2509.20435](/abs/2509.20435 "Abstract") (cross-list from cond-mat.str-el) [[pdf](/pdf/2509.20435 "Download PDF"), [other](/format/2509.20435 "Other formats")]
:   Title: Disorder-induced fractionalization of pair density waves

    [Julian May-Mann](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=May-Mann,+J), [Akshat Pandey](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Pandey,+A), [Steven A. Kivelson](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Kivelson,+S+A)

    Comments: 4 pages, 1 figure

    Subjects: Strongly Correlated Electrons (cond-mat.str-el); Superconductivity (cond-mat.supr-con)

    We investigate the effects of disorder on a system that in the clean limit is a pair density wave (PDW) superconductor. The charge order of the clean PDW is inevitably lost (via Imry-Ma), but the fate of the superconducting order is less clear. Here, we consider a strongly inhomogeneous limit in which the system consists of a random collection of PDW puddles embedded in a metallic background. When the puddles are dilute, they become phase coherent at low temperatures, resulting in a state that is macroscopically equivalent to a charge-$2e$ $s$-wave superconductor. This can be viewed as an example of ``order parameter fractionalization'' -- the PDW order splits into a charge-2e s-wave superconductor and a charge density wave, the latter of which is destroyed by disorder -- and stands in contrast to the ``vestigial'' charge-4e superconductivity which has been proposed to arise in weakly disordered PDWs.

:   Title: Uniaxial negative thermal expansion in a weak-itinerant-ferromagnetic phase of CoZr$\_{2}$H$\_{3.49}$

    [Yuto Watanabe](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Watanabe,+Y), [Kota Suzuki](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Suzuki,+K), [Takayoshi Katase](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Katase,+T), [Akira Miura](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Miura,+A), [Aichi Yamashita](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Yamashita,+A), [Yoshikazu Mizuguchi](https://arxiv.org/search/cond-mat?searchtype=author&query=Mizuguchi,+Y)

    Comments: 12 pages, 9 figures

    Subjects: Materials Science (cond-mat.mtrl-sci); Strongly Correlated Electrons (cond-mat.str-el); Superconductivity (cond-mat.supr-con)

    We discovered unique uniaxial negative thermal expansion (NTE) behavior for a weak-itinerant-ferromagnetic phase of CoZr$\_{2}$H$\_{3.49}$. CoZr$\_{2}$ is known as a superconductor exhibiting uniaxial NTE along the $c$-axis, which is called anomalous thermal expansion (ATE).
